Comprehensive Program Overview for Trainers
This document provides trainers with a complete overview of the 6-day intensive solar training program designed for implementation in Mosul, Iraq. It captures the evolution of our training design through collaborative refinement.

Program Context & Need
Mosul faces significant energy challenges that create both problems and opportunities:

Power outages: Typical homes experience 16+ hours of outages weekly
High energy costs: Diesel generators cost families approximately 250 IQD/kWh
Job potential: The solar industry can create thousands of local jobs
Climate advantage: Mosul's high solar irradiance (5+ peak sun hours daily) makes solar systems highly effective
Target Audience
This program is designed for:

Electrical/mechanical engineers transitioning to renewable energy
Technicians with basic electrical knowledge
Construction professionals interested in solar installation
Entrepreneurs looking to enter the growing solar market
Participants should have basic technical knowledge but do not need prior solar experience.

Core Learning Objectives
By the end of this program, participants will be able to:

Technical Competencies:
Conduct thorough site assessments and load calculations
Size and design complete solar PV systems
Select appropriate components based on technical specifications
Install solar systems safely following industry standards
Commission and troubleshoot installations professionally
Document system details using industry-standard forms
Business Competencies:
Calculate system costs and prepare professional quotations
Demonstrate financial benefits to potential customers
Develop service offerings for recurring revenue
Manage project cash flow effectively
Market solar services effectively in the local context
Pedagogical Approach & Principles
Our training methodology is built on these foundational principles:

Practical Before Theoretical: 70% hands-on activities, 30% classroom instruction
Local Relevance: All examples, costs, and scenarios specific to Mosul context
Progressive Complexity: Skills build systematically day by day
Authentic Materials: Using real equipment, documentation, and industry forms
Business Integration: Technical and business skills taught together
Safety Culture: Safety protocols embedded throughout all activities
Simple Language: Clear explanations that avoid unnecessary jargon
Comprehensive Program Structure
Day 1: Context, Site Auditing & Load Analysis
Learning Objectives:

Explain Iraq's energy gap and solar opportunity
Differentiate between PV system architectures (off-grid, on-grid, hybrid)
Conduct comprehensive site surveys using proper tools
Calculate accurate load profiles for residential applications
Create horizon sketches and interpret sun-path diagrams
Key Activities:

Interactive lecture on solar fundamentals
Field walk audit and site survey practice
Load calculation workshop with realistic appliances
Sun-path analysis and horizon sketching
Daily reflection and WhatsApp voice summary
Materials Needed:

Site survey worksheets
Clinometer apps installed on phones
Horizon sketch templates
Sample appliance power rating cards
Sun-path charts for Mosul latitude
Day 2: System Sizing & Financial Fundamentals
Learning Objectives:

Calculate appropriate solar array size from load data
Determine battery bank capacity for required autonomy
Select inverter size based on system requirements
Demonstrate financial benefits using simple payback and IRR
Explain advanced panel technologies and their benefits
Key Activities:

Manual system sizing workshop
IRR calculator demonstration with real scenarios
Digital tools introduction (PVWatts, Viktor)
Component technology comparisons
Materials Needed:

System sizing worksheets
IRR calculator spreadsheet
Calculators
Sample specification sheets for components
Day 3: Component Selection & Procurement
Learning Objectives:

Interpret component specification sheets correctly
Compare different products based on technical parameters
Create comprehensive Bills of Materials with all costs
Calculate Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE)
Explain series and parallel wiring configurations
Key Activities:

Specification sheet comparison exercise
Bill of Materials and LCOE workshop
Wiring demonstration (series vs parallel)
Protection devices and system safety overview
Materials Needed:

Component specification sheets (panels, inverters, batteries)
BoM worksheets
LCOE calculator templates
Small solar panels for wiring demonstration
Protection devices for hands-on inspection
Day 4: Hands-on Installation & Safety Protocols
Learning Objectives:

Follow proper safety procedures for solar installation
Install mounting systems according to specifications
Mount PV modules with correct techniques
Complete DC and AC wiring following code requirements
Document installation quality using torque logs
Key Activities:

Safety briefing and equipment demonstration
Installation workflow walk-through
Hands-on installation practice with rotation through stations
Torque logging and quality assurance documentation
Crew briefing practice
Materials Needed:

Safety equipment (hard hats, gloves, safety glasses)
Installation tools (torque wrench, drills, wire tools)
Mounting hardware and solar panels
Torque log templates
IEC-Iraq code reference sheets
Day 5: System Commissioning & Troubleshooting
Learning Objectives:

Verify system performance using commissioning checklist
Measure electrical parameters to confirm proper operation
Identify and diagnose common system faults
Interpret IV curves and thermal imaging results
Document system performance for client handover
Key Activities:

Live commissioning demonstration
Fault diagnosis and troubleshooting stations
Theory assessment quiz
Capstone project introduction
Materials Needed:

Commissioning checklists
Test equipment (multimeter, IV tracer if available)
Functional small solar system for testing
Fault simulation equipment
Theory quiz
Day 6: Business Models & Capstone Project
Learning Objectives:

Calculate proper pricing and margins for solar businesses
Develop service packages for recurring revenue
Create complete system designs from site assessment to installation
Present project proposals professionally
Identify next steps for career development
Key Activities:

Solar business finance workshop
Service package development
Capstone project completion and presentations
Certification and feedback session
Materials Needed:

Business planning templates
Cash flow worksheets
Capstone project materials
Presentation equipment
Certificates
Assessment Strategy
Our assessment approach verifies both knowledge and practical skills:

Daily Competency Checks:
Day 1: Completed site survey forms
Day 2: System sizing calculations (±5% accuracy)
Day 3: Equipment selection and BoQ creation
Day 4: Installation practice (safety protocols followed)
Day 5: Commissioning checklist completion
Day 6: Final project presentation
Capstone Project (25% of final assessment):
Complete system design based on real scenario
Component selection with justification
Financial analysis and customer proposal
Installation and safety plan
Professional presentation
Theory Assessment (25% of final assessment):
30 multiple-choice questions covering key concepts
Applied problem-solving questions
Practical Skills (50% of final assessment):
Observed technique during hands-on activities
Documentation quality
Safety protocol adherence
Troubleshooting ability
Adaptation for Mosul Context
This program has been specifically designed for implementation in Mosul, with these contextual factors addressed:

Economic Reality:
All financial calculations use local currency (IQD)
Component costs reflect Mosul market prices
Diesel cost comparisons use local fuel prices
Cash-based business models rather than financing
Technical Context:
System designs account for Mosul's climate (heat, dust)
Grid reliability factors in system architecture choices
Local building types guide mounting approaches
Local codes and practices integrated throughout
Cultural Considerations:
Formal Arabic used for instruction
Business practices respect local norms
Safety concerns acknowledge regional realities
Examples reflect typical Mosul homes and businesses
Materials Master List
Hardware Requirements:
3-4 solar panels (at least one each: mono, poly)
1-2 inverters (hybrid preferred)
Battery samples (Li-ion if possible, lead-acid)
MC4 connectors, cables, fuses
Mounting hardware (rails, clamps, brackets)
Safety equipment (hard hats, gloves, glasses)
Testing equipment (multimeter, thermal camera)
Documentation Requirements:
Site survey forms (25 copies)
System sizing worksheets (25 copies)
BoM and LCOE templates (25 copies)
Commissioning checklists (25 copies)
Specification sheets for available components
IEC code reference (Arabic preferred)
Trainer manuals with detailed session guides
Digital Resources:
IRR calculator spreadsheet
PVWatts or similar sizing tool
Component database with local pricing
Presentation slides for each day
WhatsApp group for ongoing support
Implementation Recommendations
For optimal delivery of this program, we recommend:

Trainer Preparation:
Review all materials thoroughly before delivery
Practice demonstrations, especially for technical activities
Prepare physical examples where possible
Adapt financial examples to current market prices
Facility Requirements:
Indoor classroom with tables for group work
Outdoor or dedicated space for installation practice
Electrical supply for testing equipment
Projector and whiteboard
Secure storage for equipment
Group Management:
Ideal class size: 15-25 participants
Form consistent teams of 3-5 participants
Mix skill levels within teams when possible
Build in extra time for translation if needed
Follow-up Support:
WhatsApp group for ongoing questions
Optional mentoring for graduates
Connection to local solar businesses
Refresher workshops as technology evolves
Success Indicators
The program will be considered successful when:

80%+ of participants can complete the capstone project successfully
75%+ of participants report confidence in all core competencies
50%+ of participants find employment or start businesses in solar within 6 months
Local partners report satisfaction with graduate skill levels

  - Morning preparation checklist
  - Key concepts

  - Assessment methods

- **Create bilingual (Arabic-English) visual job aids** for critical tasks like:
  - MC4 connector crimping
  - Proper torque sequence for mounting

- **Develop location-specific resources** for Mosul climate conditions and building types

- **Create a local vendor guide** listing trusted suppliers of quality components mentioned by experts

- **Include sample documents** for government loan applications and certification processes

### 4. Improve Implementation Guidance

- **Create a trainer preparation guide** with suggested practice before teaching

- **Develop a trainer observation form** for quality control during rollout

- **Add equipment and facility specifications** needed to properly conduct each module

1. **Experience and Credentials**
   - **Years in solar field:** Hussam (5 years), Muayad (14 years)
   - **Training experience:** Hussam (3 years), Muayad (10+ years)
   - **Systems designed/installed:** Hussam (several prototypes), Muayad (1,000+ government building assessments)
   - **Certifications:** Both hold RENAC Train-the-Trainer certificates from Germany

2. **Technical Implementation**
   - **Ideal panel count for training:** 4 panels minimum to demonstrate both series and parallel configurations
   - **Trainee-to-equipment ratio:** 4-5 trainees per workstation maximum
   - **Trainer-to-trainee ratio:** 1 lead trainer plus 4 assistants for 20 participants
   - **Training duration:** 4-6 days with approximately 6 hours of instruction daily

3. **Financial Metrics**
   - **System payback period:** 5-7 years according to both experts
   - **Common panel cost:** Approximately $200 for a 520W panel (Hussam)
   - **Battery costs:** $1,500-2,000 per lithium battery with 10-year lifespan (Hussam)

### Qualitative Insights

1. **Most Common Installation Failures**
   - **Poor cleaning practices:** "Panels get dusty, output drops, customers lose faith in solar" (Hussam)
   - **Inadequate mounting:** "Cheap frames cannot handle wind; arrays shift or fall" (Hussam)
   - **Incorrect wiring:** "People use AC hardware on DC lines which is unsafe" (Hussam)
   - **Counterfeit batteries:** "They open them, replace some cells, close them and sell as new" (Muayad)

2. **Effective Teaching Approaches**
   - **Peer teaching:** "Give each student a small device, let them research for 15 minutes, then present" (Hussam)
   - **Morning recall:** "Each day starts with one question about yesterday's material" (Muayad)
   - **Role play:** "One person plays customer, the other is sales engineer with a checklist" (Muayad)
   - **Real-world design:** "Each trainee designs a system for their own home" (Muayad)

3. **Key Business Challenges**
   - **Initial investment barrier:** "The obstacle is the large upfront cost" (Hussam)
   - **Certification value:** "Certificate must carry an external stamp or Ministry recognition, or banks won't value it" (Muayad)
   - **Quality control issues:** "The market wants the cheapest, not the highest quality" (Muayad)
   - **Social proof importance:** "People are convinced when they see neighbors' successful installations" (Hussam)

4. **Recommended Tools and Resources**
   - **Basic tools:** PVWatts calculator, spreadsheets (both experts)
   - **Advanced tools:** PVsyst software, HOMER for hybrid systems (Muayad)
   - **Field equipment:** Watt-meter plugs, irradiance meter, shadow analyzer (both experts)
   - **Teaching aids:** Clean vs. dirty panels for demonstration, torque specification sheets (both experts)

These insights can be compiled into a comprehensive resource guide for trainers, giving them both the hard data and practical wisdom needed to deliver effective solar training in the Iraqi context.

# DAY 1: SITE ASSESSMENT & LOAD ANALYSIS

## PREPARATION CHECKLIST

Day 2 Facilitator Guide: System Sizing & Financial Analysis
Overview
Today builds on the site survey skills from Day 1 by teaching trainees how to size a complete solar system and analyze its financial benefits. By the end of today, trainees will be able to calculate system components and demonstrate ROI to potential customers.

Detailed Activity Guide: Manual System Sizing Workshop
Purpose
Trainees learn the step-by-step process to size a complete solar system based on energy needs, ensuring they understand the underlying calculations before using software tools.
Materials

System sizing worksheets (1 per trainee)
Calculators
Whiteboard for demonstrations
Completed site survey forms from Day 1
PSH reference tables for Mosul

Preparation

Write the sizing formula steps on the whiteboard:

Daily load (kWh) × 1.2 = DC energy needed
DC energy ÷ PSH = Array wattage (Wp)
Array Wp ÷ Panel wattage = Number of panels
Daily load × Days of autonomy ÷ DoD = Battery capacity


Prepare a simple example with rounded numbers
Create groups of 3-4 trainees

Step-by-Step Procedure
1. Introduction (15 minutes)

Review the purpose of sizing: matching system capacity to customer needs
Walk through each formula on the board with a simple example:

6 kWh daily load × 1.2 = 7.2 kWh DC energy
7.2 kWh ÷ 5 PSH = 1,440 Wp array
1,440 Wp ÷ 360 W panels = 4 panels
6 kWh × 2 days ÷ 0.8 DoD = 15 kWh battery



2. Group Practice (30 minutes)

Have trainees use the load data from their Day 1 survey forms
Guide them through calculation steps on the sizing worksheet
Circulate to check calculations and provide assistance
Emphasize rounding up for panels and batteries (never down)

3. Component Selection (30 minutes)

Once array and battery sizes are calculated, discuss component selection:

Show specification sheets for available panels in the market
Discuss inverter sizing (typically 80-100% of array size)
Explain battery voltage selection (12V, 24V, 48V)


Have trainees select specific components for their design

4. Cross-Check (15 minutes)

Have teams swap calculations for peer review
Identify common mistakes and discuss as a group
Show how a 5% error in load estimation can affect final design

Common Questions & Answers
Q: "Why multiply by 1.2 for system losses?"
A: This accounts for losses in the inverter (about 5-10%), wiring resistance (2-5%), and temperature effects (5%), ensuring the system delivers the needed energy to the loads.
Q: "How many days of autonomy do we need in Mosul?"
A: For most residential systems, 1-2 days is standard. Commercial or medical facilities might need 2-3 days. This depends on customer budget and critical loads.
Q: "Should we oversize the array?"
A: It's good practice to add 10-15% extra capacity for future expansion and to account for panel degradation over time (about 0.5% per year).
Q: "What if the calculated system is too expensive for the customer?"
A: We can optimize by: 1) focusing on critical loads only, 2) reducing days of autonomy, or 3) selecting different component types (e.g., poly instead of mono panels).
Detailed Activity Guide: IRR Calculator Lab
Purpose
Trainees learn to use financial tools to demonstrate return on investment to potential customers, making a compelling business case for solar.
Materials

IRR_Slider Google Sheet (shared link)
Computers/tablets (at least 1 per team)
Projector for demonstration
Print-outs of different customer scenarios

Preparation

Prepare the Google Sheet with:

Editable cells in blue (panel quantity, battery capacity, etc.)
Formulas for calculating IRR, NPV, and payback period
Current prices for components in Mosul


Create 3-4 different customer scenarios with varying load profiles

Step-by-Step Procedure
1. Financial Concepts Introduction (20 minutes)

Explain key financial terms:

Simple payback: how long until savings = investment
IRR: percentage return accounting for time value of money
NPV: present value of all future cash flows


Demonstrate diesel costs vs. solar over time with a simple chart

2. Spreadsheet Demonstration (25 minutes)

Show the IRR_Slider spreadsheet on the projector
Walk through each input field:

System size (panels, batteries)
Component costs
Diesel/grid prices
Maintenance assumptions


Demonstrate how changing panel quantity affects IRR

3. Scenario Analysis (45 minutes)

Distribute different customer scenarios to each team
Examples:

Urban apartment with limited roof space
Rural home with no grid access
Small business with daytime operation
Clinic with critical equipment


Have teams optimize each system to achieve IRR ≥ 15%
Teams must adjust components while maintaining functionality

4. Presentation & Competition (15 minutes)

Each team briefly presents their optimized design
Award points for highest IRR while meeting customer needs
Discuss different strategies used by teams

Troubleshooting & Adaptations
If internet access is unreliable:

Have offline Excel versions of the calculator ready
Use printouts with manual calculation options

If participants struggle with financial concepts:

Focus on simple payback rather than IRR
Use visual examples showing monthly savings

Assessment Method

Check sizing worksheets for calculation accuracy (within 5%)
Observe teamwork during IRR optimization activity
Review final system designs for appropriate component matching
Ask questions to verify understanding of financial metrics

□ 25 printed spec-sheet comparison matrices
□ 25 BoM/LCOE worksheets
□ Actual specification sheets for different brands/models (min. 3 each):
□ Solar panels (mono, poly, bifacial)
□ Inverters (string, hybrid)
□ Batteries (lithium, lead-acid)
□ Mounting systems
□ Sample supplier quotations (with and without hidden fees)
□ Two small solar panels for wiring demonstration
□ MC4 connectors, wire samples, crimping tools
□ Multimeter
□ Protection devices (fuses, breakers, SPDs) for demonstration

Detailed Activity Guide: Spec-Sheet Comparison Activity
Purpose
Trainees learn to read and interpret technical specification sheets, compare different products, and select components that work together effectively for a specific system design.
Materials

Specification sheet comparison matrix (1 per trainee)
Printed specification sheets for multiple brands/models:

Solar panels (4-5 different types)
Inverters (3-4 different models)
Batteries (lithium and lead-acid options)


Highlighters or colored pens
System requirements scenario cards

Preparation

Create component stations around the room with specification sheets
Prepare scenario cards (e.g., "Urban home, limited budget, 5kW system")
Highlight key specifications on a sample sheet to demonstrate

Step-by-Step Procedure
1. Introduction to Specification Sheets (20 minutes)

Show an example specification sheet on the projector
Identify critical parameters for each component type:

Panels: wattage, efficiency, temperature coefficient, dimensions, warranty
Inverters: capacity, efficiency, MPPT voltage range, features, warranty
Batteries: capacity, DoD, cycle life, warranty


Demonstrate how to find and interpret each parameter

2. Comparison Matrix Exercise (45 minutes)

Divide trainees into groups of 3-4
Assign each group a system scenario with specific requirements
Have groups circulate through component stations
Groups must fill in their comparison matrix for each component type
Challenge: select the optimal combination of components for their scenario

3. Technical Parameters Focus (25 minutes)

Direct special attention to critical technical parameters:

Temperature coefficient (panels): critical in Mosul's hot climate
MPPT voltage window (inverters): must match string voltage
Cycle life vs DoD (batteries): key for LCOE


Have groups calculate temperature derating for Mosul summer (45°C)

4. Presentation & Discussion (30 minutes)

Each group presents their selected components
Explain reasoning for their choices (cost vs quality, compatibility)
Other groups provide feedback and ask questions
Trainer highlights good decisions and suggests improvements

Troubleshooting & Adaptations
If specification sheets are not available in sufficient quantity:

Create simplified spec sheets with just key parameters
Use digital versions on shared tablets/phones

If trainees struggle with technical parameters:

Focus on 3-4 key parameters only
Provide a decision flowchart for selection

Common Questions & Answers
Q: "How do we know if components are compatible with each other?"
A: Check voltage and current ratings. Inverter input must match panel output voltage range, battery voltage must match inverter battery input, etc.
Q: "Is it better to choose components from the same manufacturer?"
A: Not necessarily, but it can simplify warranty claims. Focus on compatibility and quality rather than brand matching.
Q: "How important is temperature coefficient in Mosul?"
A: Critical. Panels can reach 70°C in summer, reducing output by 15-20% compared to standard test conditions. Good temperature coefficients minimize this loss.
Q: "What's more important: upfront cost or warranty period?"
A: This depends on the business model. For a contractor, longer warranties reduce callback costs. For direct sales, lower upfront costs might be more attractive to customers.
Detailed Activity Guide: BoM & LCOE Workshop
Purpose
Trainees learn to create accurate Bills of Materials, calculate total system costs, and determine the Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE) to compare different system designs economically.
Materials

BoM/LCOE worksheets (1 per trainee)
Calculators
Price lists for components in local market
Computer with Excel/Google Sheets (for demonstration)
System designs from previous activities

Preparation

Create a comprehensive price list for all components and accessories
Prepare a sample BoM with all required categories
Write the LCOE formula on the board:

LCOE = Total Lifetime Cost ÷ Total Lifetime Energy Production



Step-by-Step Procedure
1. Creating a Comprehensive BoM (30 minutes)

Explain the importance of accurate and complete BoMs
Walk through each category of components:

Major components (panels, inverters, batteries)
Mounting hardware
Wiring and connectors
Protection devices
Monitoring equipment
Labor and installation


Demonstrate how to calculate quantities needed
Emphasize including ALL components (common mistake: forgetting small items)

2. Cost Estimation (30 minutes)

Using the price list, have trainees complete their BoM
Include delivery, installation, and contingency (5-10%)
Calculate total system cost
Discuss ways to optimize cost without compromising quality
Highlight the importance of including maintenance costs over system life

3. LCOE Calculation (30 minutes)

Explain the concept of LCOE as a way to compare energy sources
Walk through the calculation:

Estimate lifetime energy production (kWh)
Factor in component replacements (e.g., inverter at year 10)
Calculate IQD/kWh over 25 years


Have trainees calculate LCOE for their system designs
Compare to diesel generator cost (approx. 250 IQD/kWh)

4. Design Optimization (15 minutes)

Challenge teams to modify their designs to reduce LCOE
Discuss trade-offs between upfront cost and lifetime value
Share optimization strategies:

Component quality vs. cost
System sizing (avoiding oversizing)
Installation efficiency



Troubleshooting & Adaptations
If current market prices aren't available:

Use relative pricing (e.g., budget, mid-range, premium)
Focus on proportional costs rather than exact figures

If calculation proves difficult:

Use a simplified LCOE calculator
Focus on comparing options rather than exact values

Assessment Method

Check completed specification comparison matrices for accuracy
Review BoM completeness (missing components identified)
Evaluate LCOE calculations (within 10% of expected value)
Observe decision-making process and justifications

Detailed Activity Guide: Hands-on Installation Rotation
Purpose
Trainees gain practical experience with each step of the installation process through a station rotation system, applying safety protocols and proper installation techniques.
Materials
Station 1: Mounting System

Mounting rails and hardware
Torque wrench
Drill (if needed)
Assembly instructions
Practice surface (demo roof section or stand)

Station 2: Panel Installation

Solar panel(s)

Gloves

Wire strippers

Station 4: Safety & Quality Inspection

Inspection checklist
Thermal camera (if available)
Multimeter
IEC code reference sheet
Sample documentation forms

Preparation

Set up four distinct stations, each with required tools and materials
Assign an experienced facilitator to each station if possible
Prepare rotation schedule (15-20 minutes per station)
Create clear instruction cards for each station

Step-by-Step Procedure
1. Introduction & Safety Briefing (15 minutes)

Conduct formal safety briefing following industry standards
Demonstrate proper PPE use
Explain rotation system and time limits
Assign teams of 3-5 trainees to starting stations

2. Station Rotations (80 minutes, 20 minutes per station)
Station 1: Mounting System

Demonstrate proper rail assembly
Show correct spacing and alignment
Have trainees practice assembling a section
Emphasize proper torque specifications

Station 2: Panel Installation

Demonstrate safe panel handling (2-person lift)
Show proper clamp positioning
Have trainees install panel on rails
Practice torque checking and logging

Station 3: DC Wiring

Demonstrate wire stripping and MC4 connector assembly
Show proper wire management techniques
Have trainees make connections and test continuity
Practice labeling according to standards

Station 4: Safety & Quality Inspection

Demonstrate systematic inspection process
Show how to verify torque marks
Practice using thermal camera to check connections
Complete inspection documentation

3. Debrief (10 minutes)

Gather all groups
Each station facilitator shares common mistakes observed
Address questions and clarify techniques
Emphasize quality assurance importance

Troubleshooting & Adaptations
If outdoor installation isn't possible:

Create indoor mockups using small sections
Use pictures and videos to supplement

If limited equipment is available:

Focus on one complete system done as a group demonstration
Have trainees rotate through individual tasks

If weather is unfavorable:

Focus on indoor components (wiring, inspection)
Use simulation exercises for outdoor work

Safety Considerations

Ensure proper PPE use at all times
No energized systems during practice
Emphasize proper lifting techniques
Designate a safety monitor

Common Questions & Answers
Q: "How tight should the module clamps be?"
A: Always follow manufacturer specifications, typically 8-12 Nm. Over-tightening can damage the frame, while under-tightening allows movement.
Q: "Should cable connections be made before or after panel mounting?"
A: Usually after mounting to avoid strain on the connections, but this depends on the mounting system design. Always plan your workflow to minimize reaching over installed panels.
Q: "What's the proper spacing between panels?"
A: Follow manufacturer recommendations, typically 10-20mm, to allow for thermal expansion while maximizing space usage.
Q: "How do we ensure water doesn't get into the junction boxes or connections?"
A: Always route cables with a drip loop, ensure MC4 connectors are fully engaged (you should hear a click), and never place connections where water can pool.

2. Role Assignment & Preparation (10 minutes)

3. Briefing Practice Rotations (30 minutes)

Team members play their assigned roles

4. Feedback & Discussion (20 minutes)

Observers provide constructive feedback
Discuss effective communication techniques

Troubleshooting & Adaptations

Detailed Activity Guide: Live Commissioning Demonstration
Purpose
Trainees learn the systematic process of commissioning a solar system, testing all components to verify proper operation and performance as designed.
Materials

Functional small-scale solar system:

2-4 panels in 1-2 strings
Combiner box with disconnects
Charge controller/MPPT
Inverter
Battery bank
Monitoring system (if available)


Test equipment:

Digital multimeter
IV curve tracer (or smartphone adapter)
Insulation resistance tester
Infrared/thermal camera
Irradiance meter (optional)


Commissioning checklist (1 per trainee)
System specification sheet

Preparation

Set up a functional system ready for commissioning
Test all equipment before the session
Create a commissioning checklist matching the demonstration system
Have expected values calculated and noted for facilitator reference

Step-by-Step Procedure
1. Commissioning Overview (15 minutes)

Define commissioning: systematic process to verify system operation as designed
Explain why commissioning is critical:

Ensures safety and performance
Establishes baseline measurements
Required for warranty validation
Prevents callbacks and customer issues


Walk through commissioning checklist and sequence

2. Visual Inspection Demonstration (15 minutes)

Demonstrate systematic visual inspection:

Structural: mounting, alignment, torque marks
Electrical: wire management, connections, polarities
Safety: signage, disconnects, grounding
Code compliance: IEC requirements


Document findings on commissioning checklist

3. Electrical Testing Demonstration (40 minutes)

Demonstrate each test in sequence:

Open circuit voltage (Voc) measurement (all strings)
Short circuit current (Isc) measurement
Insulation resistance test
IV curve capture and analysis
Inverter output verification
Battery system testing (if applicable)


Show proper test equipment usage
Record results and compare to expected values
Explain acceptable ranges and what deviations indicate

4. Operational Test & Monitoring (20 minutes)

Demonstrate system startup sequence
Run "soak test" at full output (15 minutes)
Use thermal camera to check for hot spots
Verify monitoring system operation
Show how to document final readings

5. Documentation & Handover (15 minutes)

Complete all commissioning documentation
Explain importance of thorough records
Show how to create client documentation package
Discuss client training requirements

Troubleshooting & Adaptations
If full system isn't available:

Use separate component stations for each test type
Supplement with videos of complete commissioning

If advanced test equipment isn't available:

Focus on tests using basic multimeter
Use smartphone apps where possible (thermal cameras, IV tracers)
Simulate some results with prepared data

Common Questions & Answers
Q: "How much should actual measurements vary from expected values?"
A: Generally, Voc should be within ±5% of calculated values, Isc within ±10% depending on irradiance. Larger variations indicate potential issues.
Q: "What if we don't have an IV curve tracer?"
A: Basic commissioning can be done with a multimeter. Measure Voc and Isc, and make sure they're close to expected values adjusted for temperature and irradiance.
Q: "How long should the soak test run?"
A: Minimum 15 minutes at close to full power, but longer is better (up to 1 hour) to ensure thermal stability.
Q: "What documentation must we provide to the customer?"
A: At minimum: system specifications, commissioning results, warranty information, maintenance requirements, and emergency procedures.

Prepare reference solutions for facilitators
Test each fault to ensure it can be found using available tools

Step-by-Step Procedure
1. Troubleshooting Methodology (15 minutes)

Present structured approach to troubleshooting:

Observe symptoms
Check documentation/specifications
Test from source to load
Isolate the problem
Fix and verify


Discuss common fault categories:

Open circuits
Short circuits
Partial shading
Configuration errors
Connection issues


Demonstrate basic diagnostic tests

2. Team Formation & Rules (10 minutes)

DAY 2 GUIDE: SYSTEM SIZING & FINANCIAL ANALYSIS
What Trainees Will Learn Today
By the end of today, trainees will be able to:

Calculate the size of solar system needed for a home
Choose the right number of panels and batteries
Show customers how quickly solar pays for itself
Use basic tools to help with design

Materials You Need
□ Calculator (or phone calculator app)
□ System sizing worksheets (one per trainee)
□ Pencils
□ Whiteboard and markers
□ IRR calculator spreadsheet (on laptop)
□ Pictures of different solar panels
□ Paper for calculations
Before Class Starts

Write the sizing formula on the board:

Daily kWh × 1.2 = DC energy needed
DC energy ÷ Sun hours = Array size (Wp)
Array size ÷ Panel size = Number of panels
Battery size = Daily kWh × Days backup ÷ DoD


Set up laptop with IRR spreadsheet
Arrange tables for group work

Morning Session: System Sizing (9:00-12:45)
1. Start the Day (30 minutes)

Welcome everyone back
Ask: "What did we learn yesterday?" (get 3-4 responses)
Show yesterday's site survey form and explain: "Today we'll use this information to design an actual system"

What to Say: "Yesterday we learned how to assess if a building is good for solar. Today we'll learn how to calculate exactly what equipment is needed and how to show customers they'll save money."
2. Teach System Sizing (90 minutes)
Step 1: Explain the formulas on board

Show the load from yesterday (example: 5 kWh per day)
Show how to calculate losses: 5 kWh × 1.2 = 6 kWh
Explain: "We multiply by 1.2 because about 20% of energy is lost in the system"

Step 2: Calculate array size

Show how Mosul gets about 5 hours of peak sun
Calculate: 6 kWh ÷ 5 hours = 1.2 kW (or 1200 watts)
Explain: "This means we need panels totaling 1200 watts"

Step 3: Calculate panel quantity

Show a typical panel is 400W
Calculate: 1200W ÷ 400W = 3 panels
Explain: "Always round up, so we need 3 panels"

Step 4: Calculate battery size

For 2 days of backup: 5 kWh × 2 = 10 kWh
For lithium batteries (80% DoD): 10 kWh ÷ 0.8 = 12.5 kWh
Explain: "DoD means how much we can use. Lithium batteries can use 80% safely."

What to Say: "When you do these calculations correctly, your customers get exactly what they need - not too small, not too big. This saves them money and prevents problems."
3. Practice Time (60 minutes)

Give each trainee the sizing worksheet
Use a real example: "A home in Mosul with 2 fans, 1 TV, 6 lights, and a refrigerator"
Walk around and help trainees with their calculations
Check their work and correct mistakes

Tip: If trainees struggle with calculations, pair them with someone who understands better.
4. Break (15 minutes)
Afternoon Session: Financial Analysis (13:45-16:30)
1. Show How Solar Saves Money (75 minutes)
Step 1: Explain the diesel generator cost

Typical generator uses 1 liter per 3 kWh
Current diesel price in Mosul is about _____ IQD per liter
Calculate monthly cost: 5 kWh × 30 days ÷ 3 kWh/liter × diesel price
Write this number on the board

Step 2: Calculate solar system cost

Panels: 3 × 400W × 150,000 IQD = 1,800,000 IQD
Batteries: 12.5 kWh × 300,000 IQD/kWh = 3,750,000 IQD
Inverter and other parts: 1,500,000 IQD
Total system: 7,050,000 IQD

Step 3: Calculate payback time

Monthly diesel savings = (number from Step 1)
Months to pay back = System cost ÷ Monthly savings
Explain: "After this time, the customer is saving money every month"

What to Say: "This calculation is what convinces customers to buy solar. When they see they'll recover their money in 2-3 years and then save for 20+ more years, they understand the value."
2. Demonstrate IRR Calculator (45 minutes)

Show the spreadsheet on computer or projector
Explain IRR simply: "This is like the interest rate you'd get if you put your money in the bank instead"
Show how changing panel numbers affects the result
Let trainees try changing numbers to see the effect

3. Panel Technology (remaining time)

Show pictures of different panel types
Explain basic differences between mono and poly
Briefly mention bifacial panels if time allows

4. Wrap Up Day 2 (15 minutes)

Ask: "What was the most important thing you learned today?"
Preview tomorrow: "Tomorrow we'll learn about choosing the best components and calculating exact costs"
Remind trainees to bring calculators tomorrow

What to Say: "Today you learned the math that makes you a professional. Anyone can install panels, but knowing how to calculate the right system size is what makes you valuable."
Common Problems and Solutions
Problem: Trainees make calculation errors
Solution: Work through examples step by step on the board
Problem: Some trainees don't understand financial concepts
Solution: Use the simple comparison: "How many months of diesel equals the system price?"
Problem: Trainees get confused by technical terms
Solution: Create a simple glossary on the board with Arabic translations

Possible causes: shading, dirty panels, wrong angle
Show how to identify with IV curve or visual inspection
Demonstrate solution

Problem 3: Inverter error codes

Possible causes: grid voltage issues, settings incorrect
Show how to check inverter settings
Demonstrate solution

Step 3: Practice troubleshooting

Set up stations with deliberate faults if possible
Have trainees diagnose and fix issues
Provide guidance as needed

What to Say: "Good troubleshooting is like being a detective. Look for clues, test your theories, and fix the problem methodically. Guessing wastes time and may not solve the real issue."
2. Theory Assessment (45 minutes)

Distribute the theory quiz
Explain the format and time limit
Collect and grade (can be done after class)

3. Capstone Project Introduction (30 minutes)

Explain the capstone project purpose
Distribute project briefs or scenarios
Explain what teams will need to produce:

Complete system design
Component selection
Financial analysis
Installation plan


Form teams based on complementary skills

4. Wrap Up Day 5 (15 minutes)

Ask: "What was the most important thing you learned today?"
Preview tomorrow: "Tomorrow is our final day. You'll complete your projects and learn about the business side of solar"
Encourage teams to think about their projects overnight

What to Say: "Today you learned how to verify system quality and solve problems. Tomorrow you'll pull everything together into a complete project that shows all your new skills."
Common Problems and Solutions
Problem: Test equipment is limited
Solution: Focus on basic tests using multimeter and visual inspection
Problem: Creating deliberate faults might damage equipment
Solution: Use simulations or photographs of common problems
Problem: Some trainees struggle with electrical concepts
Solution: Pair technically strong and weak trainees during troubleshooting practice

DAY 6 GUIDE: BUSINESS SKILLS & FINAL PROJECT
What Trainees Will Learn Today
By the end of today, trainees will be able to:

Calculate business finances for a solar installation company
Create profitable maintenance service packages
Complete a full solar system design project
Present their project professionally
Receive certification and feedback

Materials You Need
□ Business planning materials:

Cash flow templates
Profit margin calculation sheets
Service package examples
□ Capstone project materials:
Design worksheets
Component selection forms
Financial analysis templates
Site information (photos/videos)
□ Presentation setup:
Projector/screen
Timer
Evaluation forms
□ Certificates
□ Course evaluation forms

Before Class Starts

Prepare business calculation examples
Check that all project materials are ready
Set up presentation area
Prepare certificates with names

Morning Session: Solar Business & Project Work (9:00-12:45)
1. Start the Day (30 minutes)

Welcome everyone to the final day
Ask: "What skills have you gained that will help you find work?" (get several responses)
Explain: "Today we focus on the business side and completing your projects"

What to Say: "Today we bring everything together. You've learned the technical skills; now we'll add the business knowledge that will help you earn a living from these skills."
2. Solar Business Finances (90 minutes)
Step 1: Explain solar business models

Installation contractor
Sales and installation
Maintenance provider
Combinations of these

Step 2: Calculate costs and pricing

Equipment costs (using realistic Mosul prices)
Labor costs
Transportation and overhead
Profit margin (typically 20-25%)

Step 3: Create sample quotes

Use the system we designed earlier in the week
Show complete pricing structure
Explain payment schedule:

30-50% deposit
Progress payments
Final payment after commissioning



Step 4: Discuss maintenance services

Annual cleaning (pricing, benefits)
System health checks
Monitoring services
Explain how these create ongoing revenue

What to Say: "A successful solar business needs technical skills AND business skills. Understanding costs, pricing, and cash flow is as important as knowing how to design a system."
3. Project Work Session (90 minutes)

Teams work on their capstone projects
Provide guidance and answer questions
Ensure all teams are making progress
Give time warnings (45 min, 15 min remaining)

4. Break (15 minutes)
Afternoon Session: Presentations & Certification (13:45-16:30)
1. Project Presentations (90 minutes)

Each team presents their complete project (10 minutes each)
Include:

Site assessment summary
System design and sizing
Component selection with rationale
Financial analysis and ROI
Installation approach


Other teams provide feedback
Trainers evaluate using assessment criteria

What to Say: "These presentations simulate how you would present to a customer or employer. Clear, confident communication shows you understand the material and can apply it professionally."
2. Final Assessment & Feedback (30 minutes)

Provide feedback on projects
Review key learning points from entire course
Distribute course evaluation forms
Collect completed evaluations

3. Certification & Closing (45 minutes)

Present certificates to each participant
Take photos for documentation
Final words from trainers
Explain follow-up support available
Exchange contact information for network building

What to Say: "This certificate represents significant achievement, but it's just the beginning. Your real success will come from applying these skills in the field and continuing to learn and grow."
Common Problems and Solutions
Problem: Teams work at different speeds on projects
Solution: Have extension activities for faster teams, provide extra help to slower teams
Problem: Business concepts are challenging for technical people
Solution: Use simple examples and real-world scenarios from Mosul
Problem: Some trainees may be nervous about presenting
Solution: Allow team presentations rather than individual if needed

Pedagogical Design Elements
Each day includes these key design elements, which make this program effective:

Clear Learning Objectives

Specific, observable outcomes for each day
Focus on both knowledge and practical skills


Scaffolded Learning

Each day builds on previous knowledge
Complexity increases gradually


Mixed Teaching Methods

Direct instruction for core concepts
Hands-on practice for skill development
Collaborative work for peer learning
Reflection for deeper understanding


Authentic Assessment

Real-world tasks match actual job requirements
Feedback matches industry standards
Capstone project integrates all skills


Cultural Relevance

Examples specific to Mosul context
Pricing and scenarios match local reality
Adaptations for available resources



These simplified guides provide clear direction for first-time technical trainers while maintaining professional standards and effective teaching methods.

DAY 1: CONTEXT, SITE AUDITING & LOAD ANALYSIS
LEARNING OBJECTIVES
By the end of Day 1, participants will be able to:

Explain the energy gap in Iraq and the solar opportunity
Differentiate between PV and thermal solar applications
Compare off-grid, on-grid, and hybrid system architectures
Conduct a comprehensive site survey using proper tools
Calculate accurate load profiles for residential applications
Create a horizon shading sketch and interpret sun-path diagrams
Begin to assess ROI potential for typical installations

SCHEDULE
TimeSessionFormat09:00-09:30Welcome & Energy Gap ContextInteractive lecture09:30-11:00Solar Fundamentals & System TypesSlides + Q&A11:00-11:15Break11:15-12:45Field Walk Audit & Site SurveyOutdoor activity12:45-13:45Lunch13:45-15:00Load Calculation WorkshopWorksheet exercise15:00-16:30Sun-Path Analysis & Horizon SketchingPractical activity
MATERIALS NEEDED

Site survey worksheets (1 per participant)
Clinometer app installed on phones
Compass (physical or app)
Sun-Path chart for Mosul latitude
Calculator (or calculator app)
Horizon sketch templates
Sample appliance power rating cards
Orientation map of training facility

KEY CONCEPTS

Peak Sun Hours (PSH) in Mosul region
Proper roof tilt and orientation
Shading impact on system performance
Daily/seasonal load variations
Basic ROI principles and diesel comparison

ASSESSMENT INDICATORS

Completed site survey form with accurate measurements
Properly annotated horizon sketch
Correctly calculated load table
Active participation in discussions


DAY 1: HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES
ACTIVITY 1: SITE SURVEY PRACTICE
Duration: 90 minutes
Location: Building exterior/roof (or simulated stations)
Description:
Participants split into teams of 3 and rotate through four key survey stations:

Roof Assessment - Measure tilt with clinometer, assess structure
Orientation & Shading - Use compass, mark obstacles, estimate heights
Electrical Audit - Locate distribution panel, measure breaker size
Client Interview - Practice gathering usage information from "client"

Facilitator Notes:

Ensure safety briefing before any roof access
Pre-set "challenges" at each station (e.g., shade obstacles)
Have participants photograph key findings as documentation
Debrief common mistakes after each rotation

ACTIVITY 2: LOAD CALCULATION WORKSHOP
Duration: 75 minutes
Location: Classroom
Description:
Using a case study of a typical Mosul household, participants:

List all electrical appliances and their quantities
Research or measure power ratings (Watts)
Estimate realistic daily usage hours
Calculate daily energy consumption (kWh)
Apply appropriate contingency factors
Determine critical vs. non-critical loads for backup

Facilitator Notes:

Provide reference sheet of common Iraqi appliance wattages
Demonstrate calculations for first few appliances
Have teams compare results and discuss variations
Show how different usage patterns affect system sizing

ACTIVITY 3: SUN-PATH ANALYSIS & HORIZON SKETCHING
Duration: 90 minutes
Location: Outdoor vantage point with visible horizon
Description:
Participants create a horizon sketch for the training location:

Establish North reference point using compass
Mark cardinal directions on horizon template
Measure altitude angles to key obstacles using clinometer
Draw horizon line on template
Overlay with sun-path chart for Mosul
Calculate approximate shading percentage
Discuss mitigation strategies for identified obstructions

Facilitator Notes:

Demonstrate proper sketching technique with one example
Have participants use hand-span method as backup (fist ≈ 10°)
Emphasize accuracy at key sun-path intersections
Show how to digitize using Sun-Path app (if available)
Connect findings to tomorrow's system sizing activities

CLOSING REFLECTION
Duration: 15 minutes
Location: Classroom
Participants complete a brief reflection worksheet:

Most valuable insight from today
One concept that needs clarification
How today's learning applies to a specific site they know
Questions about tomorrow's activities

• Integrate all program skills | _"Certification from recognized programs can help secure loans from the Central Bank."_ - Muayad | --- # DAY 1: SITE ASSESSMENT & LOAD ANALYSIS ## What Trainees Will Learn Today By the end of today, trainees will be able to: - Explain the solar opportunity in Iraq - Conduct a proper site survey - Calculate a home's energy needs accurately - Analyze shading and its impact on solar production - Begin to assess if a site is suitable for solar ## Materials You Need □ Site survey worksheets (25 copies) □ Clinometer app installed on phones (one per group) □ Compass (physical or smartphone app) □ Calculator or calculator app □ Solar vocabulary cards in Arabic/English □ Sun-path charts for Mosul's latitude □ Sample appliance power rating list □ Pencils and clipboards □ Building layout map of training location ## Before Class Starts - Arrange tables in groups of 4-5 trainees - Set up demonstration area - Check that clinometer apps are installed on enough phones - Post solar vocabulary in Arabic/English on walls - Identify safe outdoor locations for site survey practice - Prepare example load calculations on whiteboard ## Morning Session (9:00-12:45) ### 1. Welcome & Introduction (30 minutes) - Welcome trainees and introduce yourself - Have trainees briefly introduce themselves - Explain the 6-day program structure - Set expectations for practical, hands-on learning **What to Say**: "Welcome to this solar training program. Iraq has abundant sunshine - over 2,800 hours per year. Today we face electricity shortages and rely on expensive generators. Solar can help solve these problems while creating good jobs for you." ### 2. Solar Fundamentals (90 minutes) **Step 1: Explain the basics** - Show simple diagram of how solar panels work - Explain difference between solar thermal and PV - Show photographs of typical Iraqi installations - Define key terms (in Arabic and English): - Photovoltaic panel - Inverter - Charge controller - Battery bank - Grid-tied vs. off-grid **Step 2: System architectures** - Explain 3 main system types with simple diagrams: - Off-grid (no connection to national grid) - Grid-tied (connects to national grid) - Hybrid (connects to grid with battery backup) - Discuss which is most common in Mosul and why **Step 3: Benefits discussion** - Economic: compare to diesel generator costs - Environmental: reduced emissions, noise - Practical: reliable power during outages - Business opportunity: growing market **What to Say**: "There are three main types of solar systems. In Mosul, hybrid systems are most common because they provide backup power during outages while still using grid electricity when available. Your first job is determining which type best meets your customer's needs." ### 3. Break (15 minutes) ### 4. Site Survey Practice (90 minutes) **Step 1: Explain site survey process** - Show completed site survey form - Explain each section and why it matters - Demonstrate basic tools: - Clinometer app for measuring angles - Compass for determining orientation - Measuring techniques for dimensions **Step 2: Outdoor practice** - Take trainees to pre-selected outdoor locations - Divide into groups of 4-5 - Assign each group a different area to assess - Have them complete actual site survey forms - Instructors circulate to provide guidance **Step 3: Review findings** - Return to classroom - Each group presents key findings - Discuss challenges encountered - Highlight good observations and measurements **What to Say**: "A proper site survey prevents expensive mistakes. You need to check roof condition, orientation, shading objects, and electrical setup. These measurements will determine if the site is suitable and what system size will work." ## Afternoon Session (13:45-16:30) ### 1. Load Calculation Workshop (75 minutes) **Step 1: Explain load assessment** - Define electrical load: appliances using electricity - Show formula: Power (W) × Hours used = Energy (Wh) - Explain converting to kWh (÷1000) - Show typical Iraqi household appliances and their power ratings - Explain critical vs. non-critical loads **Step 2: Practice calculations** - Provide worksheet with typical Mosul home scenario - List common appliances: lights, TV, refrigerator, fans, etc. - Guide trainees through calculating daily energy needs - Show how to apply safety margin (multiply by 1.2) **Step 3: Group presentation** - Have groups compare results - Discuss variations in assumptions - Show how different usage patterns affect system size **What to Say**: "Accurate load calculation is critical. Underestimating leads to unhappy customers with insufficient power. Overestimating makes systems too expensive. Your ability to calculate loads correctly will determine if your systems succeed." ### 2. Sun-Path Analysis (90 minutes) **Step 1: Explain sun movement** - Show sun-path diagram for Mosul's latitude - Explain seasonal changes in sun position - Demonstrate how to read the diagram - Connect sun position to panel production **Step 2: Shading analysis** - Explain impact of shading on solar output - Show photos of common shading problems in Mosul - Demonstrate how to sketch the horizon line - Show how to overlay horizon sketch on sun-path diagram **Step 3: Practical exercise** - Take trainees outside with sun-path charts - Have them sketch the horizon line at the training location - Identify potential shading issues - Calculate approximate impact on production **What to Say**: "Even small shading can dramatically reduce solar output. A panel is like a chain - if one cell is shaded, the whole panel suffers. This is why properly analyzing the site for shading is essential for a successful installation." ### 3. Day Review & Assignment (15 minutes) - Ask: "What are the most important things you learned today?" - Preview tomorrow: "Tomorrow we'll calculate exactly what equipment is needed" - Assignment: Calculate the load for their own home **What to Say**: "Today you learned how to assess if a site is good for solar and how to calculate energy needs. These are the foundation skills that every solar professional needs. Tomorrow we'll build on this by sizing actual systems." ## Common Problems and Solutions **Problem**: Trainees struggle with clinometer app **Solution**: Pair technically-confident trainees with those who need help, or use simple hand measurement techniques as backup **Problem**: Difficult to access suitable outdoor areas **Solution**: Create simulated assessment stations in the classroom with photos and measurements if needed **Problem**: Wide variation in load calculation results **Solution**: Work through one example completely as a group before individual practice **Problem**: Language barriers with technical terms **Solution**: Consistently use both Arabic and English terms, create visual flashcards for key terms ## Cultural Notes for Mosul Context - When conducting site surveys, be respectful of property boundaries - Be aware that photographing private homes may require explicit permission - Recognize that energy usage patterns may differ during Ramadan if training occurs during this period - Acknowledge that diesel generators are a significant part of current energy solutions in Mosul --- # DAY 2: SYSTEM SIZING & FINANCIAL ANALYSIS ## What Trainees Will Learn Today By the end of today, trainees will be able to: - Calculate the correct solar array size based on load - Determine appropriate battery capacity - Select inverter size based on system requirements - Calculate system payback period and return on investment - Use simple digital tools to validate calculations ## Materials You Need □ Calculator (or calculator app) □ System sizing worksheets (25 copies) □ Financial analysis templates (25 copies) □ IRR calculator spreadsheet (on laptop/projector) □ Panel specification sheets (several types) □ Load profiles from Day 1 □ Whiteboard and markers □ Laptop and projector (if available) □ USB drives with calculation tools (if possible) ## Before Class Starts - Write the sizing formulas on whiteboard: - Array size (Wp) = Daily energy (Wh) × 1.2 ÷ PSH - Number of panels = Array size ÷ Panel wattage - Battery capacity (Wh) = Daily energy × Days of autonomy ÷ DoD - Set up laptop with spreadsheet tools - Organize tables for group work ## Morning Session (9:00-12:45) ### 1. Day 1 Review (30 minutes) - Welcome everyone back - Quick review: "What did we learn yesterday about site assessment?" - Review a completed site survey from yesterday - Explain connection to today's sizing calculations **What to Say**: "Yesterday we learned how to assess a site and calculate energy needs. Today we'll use that information to determine exactly what equipment is needed. This is where we translate customer needs into an actual system design." ### 2. System Sizing Workshop (90 minutes) **Step 1: Explain the sizing process** - Show the complete design sequence: 1. Load calculation (from yesterday) 2. Solar array sizing 3. Battery sizing 4. Inverter selection - Explain Peak Sun Hours (PSH) for Mosul (approximately 5 hours) - Discuss system losses and safety factors (× 1.2) **Step 2: Array sizing calculation** - Use a real example from yesterday: - Example: 5 kWh daily load - With losses: 5 kWh × 1.2 = 6 kWh - Array sizing: 6 kWh ÷ 5 PSH = 1.2 kWp - Do several examples with different loads - Have trainees calculate for their own examples **Step 3: Panel quantity calculation** - Show how to determine number of panels: - Example: 1.2 kWp ÷ 400W panels = 3 panels - Always round up to whole panels - Discuss standard panel sizes available in Mosul - Explain series/parallel configurations (preview of Day 3) **Step 4: Battery sizing** - Explain battery sizing concepts: - Days of autonomy (typically 1-2 for Mosul) - Depth of Discharge (DoD): - 50% for lead-acid - 80% for lithium - Calculate example: - 5 kWh × 1 day ÷ 0.5 DoD = 10 kWh battery bank - Have trainees calculate for their examples **What to Say**: "These calculations must be precise. If you undersize the system, your customer won't have enough power. If you oversize, they pay too much. Getting this right is what makes you a professional." ### 3. Inverter Selection (45 minutes) - Explain inverter sizing principles: - AC loads determine inverter size - Starting loads (surge) must be considered - DC voltage must match battery bank - Calculate example inverter size: - For most homes: 80-100% of total connected load - Example: 1.5 kW connected load = 1.5-2 kW inverter - Discuss inverter types available in Mosul market - Price considerations and quality differences **What to Say**: "The inverter converts DC power from panels and batteries into AC power for your home. Selecting the right size is critical - too small and it will fail under load, too large and it wastes money." ### 4. Break (15 minutes) ## Afternoon Session (13:45-16:30) ### 1. Financial Analysis (90 minutes) **Step 1: Explain financial calculations** - Show basic formula for payback period: - System cost ÷ Annual savings = Years to payback - Explain diesel generator costs: - Fuel consumption: approximately 1 liter per 3 kWh - Current diesel price in Mosul: [insert current price] - Maintenance costs often forgotten - Generator replacement costs **Step 2: Calculate complete example** - System cost calculation: - Panels: 3 × 400W × [current price] - Batteries: 10 kWh × [current price/kWh] - Inverter and BOS: [current price] - Total system cost - Annual savings calculation: - Daily kWh × 365 days ÷ 3 kWh/liter × diesel price - Calculate payback period and discuss **Step 3: Group practice** - Provide current component prices from Mosul market - Have groups calculate complete system cost and payback - Compare different scenarios: - Basic system (essential loads only) - Complete system (all household needs) - Discuss financing options available locally **What to Say**: "This calculation is what convinces customers to invest in solar. Most Mosul homes can recover their investment in 3-5 years, then enjoy free electricity for 20+ more years. Show them the math and they will understand the value." ### 2. Digital Tools Introduction (45 minutes) **Step 1: Demonstrate simple sizing tools** - Show PVWatts or similar online calculator - Input Mosul location data - Enter system parameters - Review results and compare to manual calculations - If internet not available, show offline spreadsheet tools - Emphasize these tools verify our manual calculations **Step 2: Hands-on practice** - Have trainees use tools to check their calculations - Discuss any significant differences - Show how to create professional system reports **What to Say**: "These digital tools help verify our calculations and create professional reports. But you must understand the manual calculations first - never depend only on software." ### 3. Advanced Panel Technology (30 minutes) - Briefly explain panel technology differences: - Monocrystalline vs. polycrystalline - PERC, half-cell, bifacial technologies - Temperature coefficients (important in Mosul heat) - Show examples of different panel types if available - Discuss price/performance tradeoffs ### 4. Day Review & Assignment (15 minutes) - Ask: "What are the most important formulas you learned today?" - Preview tomorrow: "Tomorrow we'll select specific components and calculate exact costs" - Assignment: Complete system sizing for case study home **What to Say**: "Today you learned how to calculate the exact equipment needed for a solar system and how to prove its financial benefits. Tomorrow we'll select specific components and create complete cost estimates." ## Common Problems and Solutions **Problem**: Trainees struggle with calculations **Solution**: Provide simple calculation steps on a reference card; pair stronger/weaker trainees **Problem**: Local component prices fluctuate frequently **Solution**: Focus on calculation method rather than exact prices; update price sheet regularly **Problem**: Skepticism about financial benefits **Solution**: Show real examples from Mosul with actual electricity bills and generator costs **Problem**: Varying mathematical abilities **Solution**: Create pre-calculated worksheets where trainees only need to input their specific values ## Cultural Notes for Mosul Context - Financial calculations should reflect the cash-based nature of most transactions - Emphasize the independence from unreliable grid and expensive generators - Acknowledge challenges of obtaining financing for systems - Be aware that some imported equipment may face restrictions or tariffs --- # DAY 3: COMPONENT SELECTION & SAFETY ## What Trainees Will Learn Today By the end of today, trainees will be able to: - Read and understand product specification sheets - Compare different brands and models of components - Create a complete bill of materials with accurate pricing - Understand DC vs. AC wiring safety requirements - Recognize quality components vs. counterfeit products ## Materials You Need □ Specification sheets for different components: - Solar panels (3-4 different models) - Inverters (3-4 different models) - Batteries (2-3 different types) - Mounting systems □ Component comparison matrix templates (25 copies) □ Bill of Materials templates (25 copies) □ Current price list for Mosul market □ Samples of quality vs. counterfeit components (if available) □ Wire samples (proper DC wire vs. AC wire) □ MC4 connectors and crimping tools □ Protection devices (fuses, breakers, SPDs) ## Before Class Starts - Arrange specification sheets by category - Write LCOE formula on board: System Cost ÷ Lifetime Energy = LCOE - Set up component display area - Prepare samples of proper vs. improper equipment ## Morning Session (9:00-12:45) ### 1. Day 2 Review (30 minutes) - Welcome everyone back - Quick quiz: "Who remembers how to calculate system size?" - Review completed sizing calculations from yesterday - Connect sizing to component selection **What to Say**: "Yesterday we calculated how many panels and batteries we need. Today we'll select the specific models and calculate exact costs. This is where detailed knowledge makes a significant difference in system quality and cost." ### 2. Specification Sheet Reading (90 minutes) **Step 1: Explain panel specifications** - Show actual specification sheet - Identify critical parameters: - Wattage (power output) - Voltage (Voc and Vmp) - Current (Isc and Imp) - Temperature coefficient (critical in Mosul heat) - Physical dimensions and weight - Warranty terms **Step 2: Explain battery specifications** - Show lithium and lead-acid specifications side by side - Highlight key differences: - Capacity (kWh or Ah) - Voltage (12V, 24V, or 48V) - Depth of Discharge (DoD) - Cycle life (important for LCOE) - Temperature limitations - Safety features **Step 3: Explain inverter specifications** - Show specifications for different inverter types - Identify key parameters: - Power rating (kW) - Input voltage range - Battery compatibility - Efficiency - Features (monitoring, etc.) - Warranty **Step 4: Quality indicators** - Explain how to identify quality components: - Reputable brands available in Iraq - Certification markings (CE, TÜV, etc.) - Proper labeling and serial numbers - Packaging quality - Show examples of counterfeit products if available **What to Say**: "The specification sheet tells you everything about the component. Learning to read these properly will prevent many problems. In Iraq, counterfeit products are common - I'll show you how to identify genuine quality components." ### 3. Component Comparison Exercise (45 minutes) - Divide trainees into small groups - Assign each group a system scenario (e.g., "Family home with limited budget") - Provide specification sheets for different brands - Have groups select best components for their scenario - Groups explain their choices and justification **What to Say**: "Choosing components is about balancing quality, compatibility, and cost. The cheapest option usually costs more in the long run through repairs and replacements." ### 4. Break (15 minutes) ## Afternoon Session (13:45-16:30) ### 1. Bill of Materials Creation (75 minutes) **Step 1: Explain the complete system components** - Show comprehensive list of ALL parts needed: - Major components (panels, inverter, batteries) - Mounting structure - Cables and connectors - Protection devices (fuses, breakers, SPDs) - Monitoring equipment - Installation materials - Labor costs **Step 2: Cost calculation practice** - Use current Mosul market prices - Have trainees create complete BoM for their system - Include ALL costs (transport, installation, etc.) - Calculate total system cost - Discuss potential cost optimizations **Step 3: LCOE calculation** - Explain LCOE (Levelized Cost of Energy) - Show the formula: Total lifetime cost ÷ Total lifetime energy - Calculate example LCOE - Compare to generator and grid costs **What to Say**: "A complete and accurate Bill of Materials prevents surprises. Missing even small items can reduce your profit or cause delays. Professional installers account for every wire, connector and bracket." ### 2. Electrical Safety & Components (75 minutes) **Step 1: DC vs. AC safety differences** - Explain key differences between DC and AC systems: - DC arcs don't self-extinguish like AC - DC requires special components rated for DC - Higher danger of fire with improper DC components - Show proper DC-rated components: - Cables (proper sizing and type) - Fuses and breakers - Disconnects **Step 2: Demonstrate proper components** - Show proper DC wire vs. standard AC wire - Demonstrate correct MC4 connector assembly - Show proper fuse types for solar applications - Explain grounding requirements **Step 3: Protection devices overview** - Explain each protection component: - DC circuit breakers - Surge protection devices - Rapid shutdown (if required) - Proper grounding equipment **What to Say**: "Many solar fires are caused by using the wrong components. AC wire and breakers are not safe for DC solar circuits. This is not a place to save money - proper components protect lives and property." ### 3. Counterfeit Detection (30 minutes) - Show examples of counterfeit components if available - Explain common signs of fake products: - Lithium batteries marked as higher capacity - Panels with unrealistic specifications - Missing certification markings - Poor packaging and documentation - Discuss reliable suppliers in Mosul market **What to Say**: "Counterfeit products are a serious problem in our market. A fake battery that claims 200Ah might actually be 100Ah with weights added. This cheats your customer and damages your reputation when it fails early." ### 4. Day Review & Assignment (15 minutes) - Ask: "What was the most important thing you learned today?" - Preview tomorrow: "Tomorrow we'll learn installation techniques and safety procedures" - Assignment: Complete component selection and BoM for their project **What to Say**: "Today you learned how to select quality components and calculate exact costs.
