• Present complete proposals
• Integrate all program skills | _"Certification from recognized programs can help secure loans from the Central Bank."_ - Muayad | --- # DAY 1: SITE ASSESSMENT & LOAD ANALYSIS ## What Trainees Will Learn Today By the end of today, trainees will be able to: - Explain the solar opportunity in Iraq - Conduct a proper site survey - Calculate a home's energy needs accurately - Analyze shading and its impact on solar production - Begin to assess if a site is suitable for solar ## Materials You Need □ Site survey worksheets (25 copies) □ Clinometer app installed on phones (one per group) □ Compass (physical or smartphone app) □ Calculator or calculator app □ Solar vocabulary cards in Arabic/English □ Sun-path charts for Mosul's latitude □ Sample appliance power rating list □ Pencils and clipboards □ Building layout map of training location ## Before Class Starts - Arrange tables in groups of 4-5 trainees - Set up demonstration area - Check that clinometer apps are installed on enough phones - Post solar vocabulary in Arabic/English on walls - Identify safe outdoor locations for site survey practice - Prepare example load calculations on whiteboard ## Morning Session (9:00-12:45) ### 1. Welcome & Introduction (30 minutes) - Welcome trainees and introduce yourself - Have trainees briefly introduce themselves - Explain the 6-day program structure - Set expectations for practical, hands-on learning **What to Say**: "Welcome to this solar training program. Iraq has abundant sunshine - over 2,800 hours per year. Today we face electricity shortages and rely on expensive generators. Solar can help solve these problems while creating good jobs for you." ### 2. Solar Fundamentals (90 minutes) **Step 1: Explain the basics** - Show simple diagram of how solar panels work - Explain difference between solar thermal and PV - Show photographs of typical Iraqi installations - Define key terms (in Arabic and English): - Photovoltaic panel - Inverter - Charge controller - Battery bank - Grid-tied vs. off-grid **Step 2: System architectures** - Explain 3 main system types with simple diagrams: - Off-grid (no connection to national grid) - Grid-tied (connects to national grid) - Hybrid (connects to grid with battery backup) - Discuss which is most common in Mosul and why **Step 3: Benefits discussion** - Economic: compare to diesel generator costs - Environmental: reduced emissions, noise - Practical: reliable power during outages - Business opportunity: growing market **What to Say**: "There are three main types of solar systems. In Mosul, hybrid systems are most common because they provide backup power during outages while still using grid electricity when available. Your first job is determining which type best meets your customer's needs." ### 3. Break (15 minutes) ### 4. Site Survey Practice (90 minutes) **Step 1: Explain site survey process** - Show completed site survey form - Explain each section and why it matters - Demonstrate basic tools: - Clinometer app for measuring angles - Compass for determining orientation - Measuring techniques for dimensions **Step 2: Outdoor practice** - Take trainees to pre-selected outdoor locations - Divide into groups of 4-5 - Assign each group a different area to assess - Have them complete actual site survey forms - Instructors circulate to provide guidance **Step 3: Review findings** - Return to classroom - Each group presents key findings - Discuss challenges encountered - Highlight good observations and measurements **What to Say**: "A proper site survey prevents expensive mistakes. You need to check roof condition, orientation, shading objects, and electrical setup. These measurements will determine if the site is suitable and what system size will work." ## Afternoon Session (13:45-16:30) ### 1. Load Calculation Workshop (75 minutes) **Step 1: Explain load assessment** - Define electrical load: appliances using electricity - Show formula: Power (W) × Hours used = Energy (Wh) - Explain converting to kWh (÷1000) - Show typical Iraqi household appliances and their power ratings - Explain critical vs. non-critical loads **Step 2: Practice calculations** - Provide worksheet with typical Mosul home scenario - List common appliances: lights, TV, refrigerator, fans, etc. - Guide trainees through calculating daily energy needs - Show how to apply safety margin (multiply by 1.2) **Step 3: Group presentation** - Have groups compare results - Discuss variations in assumptions - Show how different usage patterns affect system size **What to Say**: "Accurate load calculation is critical. Underestimating leads to unhappy customers with insufficient power. Overestimating makes systems too expensive. Your ability to calculate loads correctly will determine if your systems succeed." ### 2. Sun-Path Analysis (90 minutes) **Step 1: Explain sun movement** - Show sun-path diagram for Mosul's latitude - Explain seasonal changes in sun position - Demonstrate how to read the diagram - Connect sun position to panel production **Step 2: Shading analysis** - Explain impact of shading on solar output - Show photos of common shading problems in Mosul - Demonstrate how to sketch the horizon line - Show how to overlay horizon sketch on sun-path diagram **Step 3: Practical exercise** - Take trainees outside with sun-path charts - Have them sketch the horizon line at the training location - Identify potential shading issues - Calculate approximate impact on production **What to Say**: "Even small shading can dramatically reduce solar output. A panel is like a chain - if one cell is shaded, the whole panel suffers. This is why properly analyzing the site for shading is essential for a successful installation." ### 3. Day Review & Assignment (15 minutes) - Ask: "What are the most important things you learned today?" - Preview tomorrow: "Tomorrow we'll calculate exactly what equipment is needed" - Assignment: Calculate the load for their own home **What to Say**: "Today you learned how to assess if a site is good for solar and how to calculate energy needs. These are the foundation skills that every solar professional needs. Tomorrow we'll build on this by sizing actual systems." ## Common Problems and Solutions **Problem**: Trainees struggle with clinometer app **Solution**: Pair technically-confident trainees with those who need help, or use simple hand measurement techniques as backup **Problem**: Difficult to access suitable outdoor areas **Solution**: Create simulated assessment stations in the classroom with photos and measurements if needed **Problem**: Wide variation in load calculation results **Solution**: Work through one example completely as a group before individual practice **Problem**: Language barriers with technical terms **Solution**: Consistently use both Arabic and English terms, create visual flashcards for key terms ## Cultural Notes for Mosul Context - When conducting site surveys, be respectful of property boundaries - Be aware that photographing private homes may require explicit permission - Recognize that energy usage patterns may differ during Ramadan if training occurs during this period - Acknowledge that diesel generators are a significant part of current energy solutions in Mosul --- # DAY 2: SYSTEM SIZING & FINANCIAL ANALYSIS ## What Trainees Will Learn Today By the end of today, trainees will be able to: - Calculate the correct solar array size based on load - Determine appropriate battery capacity - Select inverter size based on system requirements - Calculate system payback period and return on investment - Use simple digital tools to validate calculations ## Materials You Need □ Calculator (or calculator app) □ System sizing worksheets (25 copies) □ Financial analysis templates (25 copies) □ IRR calculator spreadsheet (on laptop/projector) □ Panel specification sheets (several types) □ Load profiles from Day 1 □ Whiteboard and markers □ Laptop and projector (if available) □ USB drives with calculation tools (if possible) ## Before Class Starts - Write the sizing formulas on whiteboard: - Array size (Wp) = Daily energy (Wh) × 1.2 ÷ PSH - Number of panels = Array size ÷ Panel wattage - Battery capacity (Wh) = Daily energy × Days of autonomy ÷ DoD - Set up laptop with spreadsheet tools - Organize tables for group work ## Morning Session (9:00-12:45) ### 1. Day 1 Review (30 minutes) - Welcome everyone back - Quick review: "What did we learn yesterday about site assessment?" - Review a completed site survey from yesterday - Explain connection to today's sizing calculations **What to Say**: "Yesterday we learned how to assess a site and calculate energy needs. Today we'll use that information to determine exactly what equipment is needed. This is where we translate customer needs into an actual system design." ### 2. System Sizing Workshop (90 minutes) **Step 1: Explain the sizing process** - Show the complete design sequence: 1. Load calculation (from yesterday) 2. Solar array sizing 3. Battery sizing 4. Inverter selection - Explain Peak Sun Hours (PSH) for Mosul (approximately 5 hours) - Discuss system losses and safety factors (× 1.2) **Step 2: Array sizing calculation** - Use a real example from yesterday: - Example: 5 kWh daily load - With losses: 5 kWh × 1.2 = 6 kWh - Array sizing: 6 kWh ÷ 5 PSH = 1.2 kWp - Do several examples with different loads - Have trainees calculate for their own examples **Step 3: Panel quantity calculation** - Show how to determine number of panels: - Example: 1.2 kWp ÷ 400W panels = 3 panels - Always round up to whole panels - Discuss standard panel sizes available in Mosul - Explain series/parallel configurations (preview of Day 3) **Step 4: Battery sizing** - Explain battery sizing concepts: - Days of autonomy (typically 1-2 for Mosul) - Depth of Discharge (DoD): - 50% for lead-acid - 80% for lithium - Calculate example: - 5 kWh × 1 day ÷ 0.5 DoD = 10 kWh battery bank - Have trainees calculate for their examples **What to Say**: "These calculations must be precise. If you undersize the system, your customer won't have enough power. If you oversize, they pay too much. Getting this right is what makes you a professional." ### 3. Inverter Selection (45 minutes) - Explain inverter sizing principles: - AC loads determine inverter size - Starting loads (surge) must be considered - DC voltage must match battery bank - Calculate example inverter size: - For most homes: 80-100% of total connected load - Example: 1.5 kW connected load = 1.5-2 kW inverter - Discuss inverter types available in Mosul market - Price considerations and quality differences **What to Say**: "The inverter converts DC power from panels and batteries into AC power for your home. Selecting the right size is critical - too small and it will fail under load, too large and it wastes money." ### 4. Break (15 minutes) ## Afternoon Session (13:45-16:30) ### 1. Financial Analysis (90 minutes) **Step 1: Explain financial calculations** - Show basic formula for payback period: - System cost ÷ Annual savings = Years to payback - Explain diesel generator costs: - Fuel consumption: approximately 1 liter per 3 kWh - Current diesel price in Mosul: [insert current price] - Maintenance costs often forgotten - Generator replacement costs **Step 2: Calculate complete example** - System cost calculation: - Panels: 3 × 400W × [current price] - Batteries: 10 kWh × [current price/kWh] - Inverter and BOS: [current price] - Total system cost - Annual savings calculation: - Daily kWh × 365 days ÷ 3 kWh/liter × diesel price - Calculate payback period and discuss **Step 3: Group practice** - Provide current component prices from Mosul market - Have groups calculate complete system cost and payback - Compare different scenarios: - Basic system (essential loads only) - Complete system (all household needs) - Discuss financing options available locally **What to Say**: "This calculation is what convinces customers to invest in solar. Most Mosul homes can recover their investment in 3-5 years, then enjoy free electricity for 20+ more years. Show them the math and they will understand the value." ### 2. Digital Tools Introduction (45 minutes) **Step 1: Demonstrate simple sizing tools** - Show PVWatts or similar online calculator - Input Mosul location data - Enter system parameters - Review results and compare to manual calculations - If internet not available, show offline spreadsheet tools - Emphasize these tools verify our manual calculations **Step 2: Hands-on practice** - Have trainees use tools to check their calculations - Discuss any significant differences - Show how to create professional system reports **What to Say**: "These digital tools help verify our calculations and create professional reports. But you must understand the manual calculations first - never depend only on software." ### 3. Advanced Panel Technology (30 minutes) - Briefly explain panel technology differences: - Monocrystalline vs. polycrystalline - PERC, half-cell, bifacial technologies - Temperature coefficients (important in Mosul heat) - Show examples of different panel types if available - Discuss price/performance tradeoffs ### 4. Day Review & Assignment (15 minutes) - Ask: "What are the most important formulas you learned today?" - Preview tomorrow: "Tomorrow we'll select specific components and calculate exact costs" - Assignment: Complete system sizing for case study home **What to Say**: "Today you learned how to calculate the exact equipment needed for a solar system and how to prove its financial benefits. Tomorrow we'll select specific components and create complete cost estimates." ## Common Problems and Solutions **Problem**: Trainees struggle with calculations **Solution**: Provide simple calculation steps on a reference card; pair stronger/weaker trainees **Problem**: Local component prices fluctuate frequently **Solution**: Focus on calculation method rather than exact prices; update price sheet regularly **Problem**: Skepticism about financial benefits **Solution**: Show real examples from Mosul with actual electricity bills and generator costs **Problem**: Varying mathematical abilities **Solution**: Create pre-calculated worksheets where trainees only need to input their specific values ## Cultural Notes for Mosul Context - Financial calculations should reflect the cash-based nature of most transactions - Emphasize the independence from unreliable grid and expensive generators - Acknowledge challenges of obtaining financing for systems - Be aware that some imported equipment may face restrictions or tariffs --- # DAY 3: COMPONENT SELECTION & SAFETY ## What Trainees Will Learn Today By the end of today, trainees will be able to: - Read and understand product specification sheets - Compare different brands and models of components - Create a complete bill of materials with accurate pricing - Understand DC vs. AC wiring safety requirements - Recognize quality components vs. counterfeit products ## Materials You Need □ Specification sheets for different components: - Solar panels (3-4 different models) - Inverters (3-4 different models) - Batteries (2-3 different types) - Mounting systems □ Component comparison matrix templates (25 copies) □ Bill of Materials templates (25 copies) □ Current price list for Mosul market □ Samples of quality vs. counterfeit components (if available) □ Wire samples (proper DC wire vs. AC wire) □ MC4 connectors and crimping tools □ Protection devices (fuses, breakers, SPDs) ## Before Class Starts - Arrange specification sheets by category - Write LCOE formula on board: System Cost ÷ Lifetime Energy = LCOE - Set up component display area - Prepare samples of proper vs. improper equipment ## Morning Session (9:00-12:45) ### 1. Day 2 Review (30 minutes) - Welcome everyone back - Quick quiz: "Who remembers how to calculate system size?" - Review completed sizing calculations from yesterday - Connect sizing to component selection **What to Say**: "Yesterday we calculated how many panels and batteries we need. Today we'll select the specific models and calculate exact costs. This is where detailed knowledge makes a significant difference in system quality and cost." ### 2. Specification Sheet Reading (90 minutes) **Step 1: Explain panel specifications** - Show actual specification sheet - Identify critical parameters: - Wattage (power output) - Voltage (Voc and Vmp) - Current (Isc and Imp) - Temperature coefficient (critical in Mosul heat) - Physical dimensions and weight - Warranty terms **Step 2: Explain battery specifications** - Show lithium and lead-acid specifications side by side - Highlight key differences: - Capacity (kWh or Ah) - Voltage (12V, 24V, or 48V) - Depth of Discharge (DoD) - Cycle life (important for LCOE) - Temperature limitations - Safety features **Step 3: Explain inverter specifications** - Show specifications for different inverter types - Identify key parameters: - Power rating (kW) - Input voltage range - Battery compatibility - Efficiency - Features (monitoring, etc.) - Warranty **Step 4: Quality indicators** - Explain how to identify quality components: - Reputable brands available in Iraq - Certification markings (CE, TÜV, etc.) - Proper labeling and serial numbers - Packaging quality - Show examples of counterfeit products if available **What to Say**: "The specification sheet tells you everything about the component. Learning to read these properly will prevent many problems. In Iraq, counterfeit products are common - I'll show you how to identify genuine quality components." ### 3. Component Comparison Exercise (45 minutes) - Divide trainees into small groups - Assign each group a system scenario (e.g., "Family home with limited budget") - Provide specification sheets for different brands - Have groups select best components for their scenario - Groups explain their choices and justification **What to Say**: "Choosing components is about balancing quality, compatibility, and cost. The cheapest option usually costs more in the long run through repairs and replacements." ### 4. Break (15 minutes) ## Afternoon Session (13:45-16:30) ### 1. Bill of Materials Creation (75 minutes) **Step 1: Explain the complete system components** - Show comprehensive list of ALL parts needed: - Major components (panels, inverter, batteries) - Mounting structure - Cables and connectors - Protection devices (fuses, breakers, SPDs) - Monitoring equipment - Installation materials - Labor costs **Step 2: Cost calculation practice** - Use current Mosul market prices - Have trainees create complete BoM for their system - Include ALL costs (transport, installation, etc.) - Calculate total system cost - Discuss potential cost optimizations **Step 3: LCOE calculation** - Explain LCOE (Levelized Cost of Energy) - Show the formula: Total lifetime cost ÷ Total lifetime energy - Calculate example LCOE - Compare to generator and grid costs **What to Say**: "A complete and accurate Bill of Materials prevents surprises. Missing even small items can reduce your profit or cause delays. Professional installers account for every wire, connector and bracket." ### 2. Electrical Safety & Components (75 minutes) **Step 1: DC vs. AC safety differences** - Explain key differences between DC and AC systems: - DC arcs don't self-extinguish like AC - DC requires special components rated for DC - Higher danger of fire with improper DC components - Show proper DC-rated components: - Cables (proper sizing and type) - Fuses and breakers - Disconnects **Step 2: Demonstrate proper components** - Show proper DC wire vs. standard AC wire - Demonstrate correct MC4 connector assembly - Show proper fuse types for solar applications - Explain grounding requirements **Step 3: Protection devices overview** - Explain each protection component: - DC circuit breakers - Surge protection devices - Rapid shutdown (if required) - Proper grounding equipment **What to Say**: "Many solar fires are caused by using the wrong components. AC wire and breakers are not safe for DC solar circuits. This is not a place to save money - proper components protect lives and property." ### 3. Counterfeit Detection (30 minutes) - Show examples of counterfeit components if available - Explain common signs of fake products: - Lithium batteries marked as higher capacity - Panels with unrealistic specifications - Missing certification markings - Poor packaging and documentation - Discuss reliable suppliers in Mosul market **What to Say**: "Counterfeit products are a serious problem in our market. A fake battery that claims 200Ah might actually be 100Ah with weights added. This cheats your customer and damages your reputation when it fails early." ### 4. Day Review & Assignment (15 minutes) - Ask: "What was the most important thing you learned today?" - Preview tomorrow: "Tomorrow we'll learn installation techniques and safety procedures" - Assignment: Complete component selection and BoM for their project **What to Say**: "Today you learned how to select quality components and calculate exact costs. This knowledge helps you make accurate quotes that win business while ensuring quality installations." ## Common Problems and Solutions **Problem**: Overwhelming number of specifications **Solution**: Create a simple checklist of the 5-6 most important specifications for each component type **Problem**: Limited knowledge of available products in Mosul **Solution**: Provide a list of common brands/models available locally with typical price ranges **Problem**: Difficulty identifying counterfeit products **Solution**: Show side-by-side comparisons and provide a simple checklist of warning signs **Problem**: Trainees unfamiliar with electrical safety concepts **Solution**: Use simple demonstrations and visual aids rather than technical explanations ## Cultural Notes for Mosul Context - Be aware that many components may come through informal supply chains - Recognize that warranties may be difficult to enforce with some suppliers - Acknowledge the challenge of balancing quality with affordability in the local market - Discuss local regulations regarding electrical work (if applicable)

Overview

Detailed Activity Guide: Manual System Sizing Workshop
Purpose
Trainees learn the step-by-step process to size a complete solar system based on energy needs, ensuring they understand the underlying calculations before using software tools.
Materials

System sizing worksheets (1 per trainee)
Calculators
Whiteboard for demonstrations
Completed site survey forms from Day 1
PSH reference tables for Mosul

Preparation

Write the sizing formula steps on the whiteboard:

Daily load (kWh) × 1.2 = DC energy needed
DC energy ÷ PSH = Array wattage (Wp)
Array Wp ÷ Panel wattage = Number of panels
Daily load × Days of autonomy ÷ DoD = Battery capacity


Prepare a simple example with rounded numbers
Create groups of 3-4 trainees

Step-by-Step Procedure
1. Introduction (15 minutes)

Review the purpose of sizing: matching system capacity to customer needs
Walk through each formula on the board with a simple example:

6 kWh daily load × 1.2 = 7.2 kWh DC energy
7.2 kWh ÷ 5 PSH = 1,440 Wp array
1,440 Wp ÷ 360 W panels = 4 panels
6 kWh × 2 days ÷ 0.8 DoD = 15 kWh battery



2. Group Practice (30 minutes)

Have trainees use the load data from their Day 1 survey forms
Guide them through calculation steps on the sizing worksheet
Circulate to check calculations and provide assistance
Emphasize rounding up for panels and batteries (never down)

3. Component Selection (30 minutes)

Once array and battery sizes are calculated, discuss component selection:

Show specification sheets for available panels in the market
Discuss inverter sizing (typically 80-100% of array size)
Explain battery voltage selection (12V, 24V, 48V)


Have trainees select specific components for their design

4. Cross-Check (15 minutes)

Have teams swap calculations for peer review
Identify common mistakes and discuss as a group
Show how a 5% error in load estimation can affect final design

Common Questions & Answers
Q: "Why multiply by 1.2 for system losses?"
A: This accounts for losses in the inverter (about 5-10%), wiring resistance (2-5%), and temperature effects (5%), ensuring the system delivers the needed energy to the loads.
Q: "How many days of autonomy do we need in Mosul?"
A: For most residential systems, 1-2 days is standard. Commercial or medical facilities might need 2-3 days. This depends on customer budget and critical loads.
Q: "Should we oversize the array?"
A: It's good practice to add 10-15% extra capacity for future expansion and to account for panel degradation over time (about 0.5% per year).
Q: "What if the calculated system is too expensive for the customer?"
A: We can optimize by: 1) focusing on critical loads only, 2) reducing days of autonomy, or 3) selecting different component types (e.g., poly instead of mono panels).
Detailed Activity Guide: IRR Calculator Lab
Purpose
Trainees learn to use financial tools to demonstrate return on investment to potential customers, making a compelling business case for solar.
Materials

IRR_Slider Google Sheet (shared link)
Computers/tablets (at least 1 per team)
Projector for demonstration
Print-outs of different customer scenarios

Preparation

Prepare the Google Sheet with:

Editable cells in blue (panel quantity, battery capacity, etc.)
Formulas for calculating IRR, NPV, and payback period
Current prices for components in Mosul


Create 3-4 different customer scenarios with varying load profiles

Step-by-Step Procedure
1. Financial Concepts Introduction (20 minutes)

Explain key financial terms:

Simple payback: how long until savings = investment
IRR: percentage return accounting for time value of money
NPV: present value of all future cash flows


Demonstrate diesel costs vs. solar over time with a simple chart

2. Spreadsheet Demonstration (25 minutes)

Show the IRR_Slider spreadsheet on the projector
Walk through each input field:

System size (panels, batteries)
Component costs
Diesel/grid prices
Maintenance assumptions


Demonstrate how changing panel quantity affects IRR

3. Scenario Analysis (45 minutes)

Distribute different customer scenarios to each team
Examples:

Urban apartment with limited roof space
Rural home with no grid access
Small business with daytime operation
Clinic with critical equipment


Have teams optimize each system to achieve IRR ≥ 15%
Teams must adjust components while maintaining functionality

4. Presentation & Competition (15 minutes)

Each team briefly presents their optimized design
Award points for highest IRR while meeting customer needs
Discuss different strategies used by teams

Troubleshooting & Adaptations
If internet access is unreliable:

Have offline Excel versions of the calculator ready
Use printouts with manual calculation options

If participants struggle with financial concepts:

Focus on simple payback rather than IRR
Use visual examples showing monthly savings

Assessment Method

Check sizing worksheets for calculation accuracy (within 5%)
Observe teamwork during IRR optimization activity
Review final system designs for appropriate component matching
Ask questions to verify understanding of financial metrics

   - Explain three main architectures with diagrams:

     - Grid-tied (متصل بالشبكة): Connects to grid, no batteries

"In Mosul, we typically see hybrid systems most often because they provide backup power during frequent grid outages. A hybrid solar system with batteries allows customers to have 24-hour power without the noise, maintenance, and fuel costs of generators."

**Common Questions & Answers:**

## Detailed Activity Guide: Load Calculation Workshop
**Purpose:** Learn to accurately calculate a customer's energy needs, which is fundamental to proper system sizing.

**Materials:**
- Load calculation worksheets
- Calculators
- Appliance power reference charts
- Whiteboard and markers
- Sample home scenario descriptions

**Preparation:**
- Write calculation formula on board: Power (W) × Hours = Energy (Wh)
- Prepare typical Mosul home example with common appliances
- Create table on board for demonstration calculation
- Prepare list of common Iraqi appliance power ratings

**Step-by-Step Procedure:**
1. **Explain Load Assessment (15 minutes)**
   - Define electrical load: appliances using electricity
   - Show the calculation formula: Power (W) × Hours = Energy (Wh)
   - Explain converting to kWh (÷1000)
   - Differentiate between:
     - Continuous loads (refrigerator)
     - Intermittent loads (TV, lights)
     - High-surge loads (water pump, AC)

2. **Demonstrate Calculation (20 minutes)**
   - Use a typical Mosul home example:
     - 8 LED lights (10W each) × 5 hours = 400 Wh
     - 1 Refrigerator (150W) × 24 hours × 0.4 (duty cycle) = 1,440 Wh
     - 2 Ceiling fans (70W each) × 8 hours = 1,120 Wh
     - 1 TV (120W) × 6 hours = 720 Wh
     - Total = 3,680 Wh = 3.68 kWh daily
   - Apply safety margin (multiply by 1.2) = 4.42 kWh
   - Explain importance of accuracy in estimations

3. **Practice Calculations (30 minutes)**
   - Provide worksheet with blank load table
   - Have trainees work in pairs to calculate:
     - Their own home loads
     - OR provided case study scenario
   - Circulate to check calculations and assist
   - Address common errors and questions

4. **Critical vs. Non-critical Loads (20 minutes)**
   - Explain concept of load prioritization
   - Have trainees mark which loads are critical
   - Discuss how this affects system design
   - Calculate sub-total for critical loads only
   - Explain backup circuit design concept

**What to Say:**
"Accurate load calculation is the foundation of good system design. If you underestimate, the customer won't have enough power. If you overestimate, the system becomes unnecessarily expensive. In Mosul, load patterns change seasonally - air conditioners in summer, heaters in winter. Always discuss these seasonal variations with customers."

**Common Questions & Answers:**
Q: "How do we handle appliances that don't run continuously, like refrigerators?"
A: "Use a duty cycle factor. Refrigerators typically run 30-40% of the time, so multiply the hours by 0.3-0.4."

Q: "What about air conditioners? They use a lot of power."
A: "Air conditioners are challenging because they have high surge currents and variable consumption. For a 1.5 ton AC (common in Mosul), calculate about 1,500W × hours used × 0.7 (typical duty cycle)."

**Troubleshooting & Adaptations:**
If trainees struggle with calculations:
- Work through examples step by step on the board
- Provide pre-calculated examples to compare
- Use simple rounded numbers

If load patterns are very different from examples:
- Ask trainees to share typical household usage from their experience
- Adjust examples to match local conditions
- Discuss how different economic levels affect energy usage

**Assessment Method:**
- Check load calculation accuracy (within 10%)
- Verify understanding of duty cycles
- Observe ability to identify critical loads
- Review completed worksheets for thoroughness

   - Demonstrate how to read the diagram
   - Explain impact of shading at different times

2. **Horizon Sketching Technique (15 minutes)**
   - Demonstrate how to create a horizon sketch:
     - Establish North reference with compass
     - Hold horizon template at eye level
     - Align with horizon
     - Mark obstacle heights using clinometer
   - Show example of completed sketch
   - Explain how to overlay on sun-path diagram

3. **Practical Exercise (45 minutes)**
   - Take trainees outside to observation point
   - Have them work in pairs:

4. **Analysis & Discussion (15 minutes)**

   - Discuss potential solutions:
     - Relocating array
     - Raising mounting height
     - Removing obstructions (if possible)
   - Connect analysis to system output expectations

**What to Say:**
"Shading is one of the biggest killers of solar performance. Even partial shading of one panel can reduce an entire string's output by 30% or more. In Mosul, we need to be especially careful with winter shading when the sun is lower in the sky. This simple horizon sketch saves us from expensive mistakes."

**Common Questions & Answers:**
Q: "Do we need to worry about small objects like antennas or small trees?"
A: "Yes. Even thin objects like antennas can cause significant power loss if they cast shadows directly on panels. Always record everything that rises above the horizon."

Q: "What if we can't avoid some shading?"

**Troubleshooting & Adaptations:**

- Create simulated horizon exercise using room features

If clinometer apps aren't available:

- Create simple cardboard clinometers
- Use angle estimation based on reference objects

**Assessment Method:**
- Check horizon sketches for:
  - Correct orientation to North
  - Accurate obstacle heights
  - Proper overlay with sun-path chart
- Observe proper use of measurement tools
- Assess understanding of shading impact through discussion

## Detailed Activity Guide: System Sizing Workshop
**Purpose:** Learn to calculate the exact size of solar array, battery bank, and inverter needed for a specific energy load.

**Materials:**
- System sizing worksheets (1 per trainee)
- Calculators
- Whiteboard for demonstrations
- Completed load calculations from Day 1
- PSH reference data for Mosul

**Preparation:**
- Write the sizing formula steps on the whiteboard:
  - Daily load (kWh) × 1.2 = DC energy needed
  - DC energy ÷ PSH = Array wattage (Wp)
  - Array Wp ÷ Panel wattage = Number of panels
  - Battery capacity = Daily load × Days autonomy ÷ DoD
- Prepare a simple example with rounded numbers
- Create groups of 3-4 trainees

**Step-by-Step Procedure:**
1. **Sizing Process Introduction (15 minutes)**
   - Explain the complete sizing sequence:
     - Start with daily load (from Day 1)
     - Calculate system losses
     - Determine array size based on available sunlight
     - Calculate battery capacity for backup needs
     - Select appropriate inverter
   - Explain Peak Sun Hours (PSH) for Mosul (~5 hours average)
   - Discuss seasonal variations in PSH

2. **Array Sizing Demonstration (25 minutes)**
   - Work through complete example on whiteboard:
     - 5 kWh daily load × 1.2 = 6 kWh with losses
     - 6 kWh ÷ 5 PSH = 1.2 kWp array size
     - Using 400W panels: 1,200W ÷ 400W = 3 panels
     - Always round up: 3 panels required
   - Explain each calculation step clearly
   - Discuss why we include the 1.2 factor:
     - Inverter losses (5-10%)
     - Wiring losses (2-5%)
     - Temperature losses (5-10%)
     - Dust accumulation (5%)

3. **Battery Sizing Demonstration (25 minutes)**
   - Continue with same example:
     - Determine days of autonomy (typically 1-2 for Mosul)
     - Calculate battery capacity: 5 kWh × 1 day = 5 kWh
     - Apply Depth of Discharge (DoD) factor:
       - Lead-acid: 5 kWh ÷ 0.5 = 10 kWh
       - Lithium: 5 kWh ÷ 0.8 = 6.25 kWh
   - Explain battery types and considerations
   - Discuss battery bank voltage (12V, 24V, 48V)

4. **Inverter Sizing (15 minutes)**
   - Explain inverter sizing principles:
     - Match to total AC loads
     - Account for surge requirements
     - Consider future expansion
   - Example: For 5 kWh system with 1.5 kW maximum load
     - Select 2 kW inverter for headroom
   - Discuss pure sine wave vs. modified sine wave

5. **Guided Practice (40 minutes)**
   - Have trainees use their own load calculations from Day 1
   - Guide them through each calculation step
   - Circulate to check work and provide assistance
   - Compare results and discuss variations

**What to Say:**
"In Mosul's hot climate, we must account for temperature losses. Panels lose efficiency as they heat up, typically 0.4% per degree above 25°C. When summer temperatures reach 45°C, panels may operate 20°C above ambient temperature, meaning they could be at 65°C and lose about 16% efficiency. This is why our calculations include loss factors."

**Common Questions & Answers:**
Q: "Why multiply by 1.2 for system losses?"
A: "This accounts for losses in the inverter (about 5-10%), wiring resistance (2-5%), temperature effects (5-10%), and dust (5%). In Mosul's climate, these factors are significant."

Q: "How many days of autonomy do we need in Mosul?"
A: "For most residential systems, 1-2 days is standard. Commercial or medical facilities might need 2-3 days. This depends on customer budget and critical loads."

Q: "Should we oversize the array?"
A: "It's good practice to add 10-15% extra capacity for future expansion and to account for panel degradation over time (about 0.5% per year)."

**Troubleshooting & Adaptations:**
If trainees struggle with calculations:
- Break down each step into smaller sub-steps
- Provide a calculation reference card
- Have stronger trainees assist those having difficulty

If calculator access is limited:
- Work in pairs or small groups
- Use smartphone calculator apps
- Prepare pre-calculated examples as references

**Assessment Method:**
- Check sizing worksheets for calculation accuracy (within 5%)
- Verify correct application of loss factors
- Confirm appropriate component quantities (must round up)
- Ask questions to verify understanding of sizing principles

## Detailed Activity Guide: Financial Analysis
**Purpose:** Enable trainees to calculate system costs and demonstrate financial benefits to customers, making a compelling case for solar investment.

**Materials:**
- Financial analysis templates
- Calculators
- Current Mosul market price list for components
- Current diesel price data
- Whiteboard or flipchart
- Excel or Google Sheet for demonstrations (if available)

**Preparation:**
- Gather current market prices for all system components
- Update diesel price information (currently ~1,000-1,200 IQD/liter in Mosul)
- Prepare a simple financial analysis example
- Create a cost comparison chart on whiteboard

**Step-by-Step Procedure:**
1. **Cost Calculation (30 minutes)**
   - Calculate complete system cost using local prices:
     - Panels: 3 × 400W × 150,000 IQD = 1,800,000 IQD
     - Batteries: 10 kWh × 300,000 IQD/kWh = 3,000,000 IQD
     - Inverter & BOS: 1,500,000 IQD
     - Installation & labor: 500,000 IQD
     - Total: 6,800,000 IQD
   - Discuss price variations between brands
   - Explain how to create accurate quotes

2. **Generator Cost Analysis (30 minutes)**
   - Calculate current generator expenses:
     - Fuel consumption: 1 liter diesel per 3 kWh
     - For 5 kWh/day: 5 ÷ 3 = 1.67 liters daily
     - Daily cost: 1.67 × 1,000 IQD = 1,670 IQD
     - Monthly cost: 1,670 × 30 = 50,100 IQD
     - Annual cost: 50,100 × 12 = 601,200 IQD
   - Add maintenance costs:
     - Oil changes: 25,000 IQD × 4 per year = 100,000 IQD
     - Filters, etc.: 50,000 IQD per year
     - Total annual generator cost: 751,200 IQD

3. **Simple Payback Calculation (20 minutes)**
   - Calculate simple payback period:
     - System cost ÷ Annual savings = Years to payback
     - 6,800,000 ÷ 751,200 = 9.05 years
   - Discuss factors affecting payback:
     - Increasing diesel prices (shortening payback)
     - System maintenance costs
     - Battery replacement (typically 5-10 years)

4. **ROI Discussion (25 minutes)**
   - Explain Return on Investment concept
   - Calculate 25-year savings:
     - Annual savings × 25 years - System cost - Battery replacement
     - 751,200 × 25 - 6,800,000 - 3,000,000 = 8,980,000 IQD
   - Discuss how to present this to customers effectively
   - Compare to bank interest rates in Iraq

**What to Say:**
"In Mosul, diesel generators are expensive to run and maintain. For a typical family using 5 kWh daily, they might spend over 750,000 IQD annually on fuel and maintenance. A solar system can recover its cost in about 9 years under current prices. But remember, diesel prices tend to rise, while solar costs remain fixed after installation. Also, solar systems increase property value and provide reliable power without noise or pollution."

**Common Questions & Answers:**
Q: "What if diesel prices change?"
A: "Higher diesel prices improve solar ROI. For every 100 IQD increase in diesel price, payback time typically decreases by 8-10 months. We can create sensitivity analyses to show customers different scenarios."

Q: "Do customers really care about payback or just upfront cost?"
A: "Both matter. Most customers in Mosul are primarily concerned with reliable power, but showing financial benefits helps justify the investment. Break it down into monthly savings that they can compare to their current generator expenses."

**Troubleshooting & Adaptations:**
If trainees struggle with financial concepts:
- Focus on simple payback rather than complex ROI
- Use monthly rather than annual figures (closer to how people budget)
- Create visual charts comparing costs over time

If market prices vary significantly:
- Work with ranges rather than specific figures
- Focus on the calculation method rather than exact results
- Create multiple scenarios (budget, mid-range, premium)

**Assessment Method:**
- Check financial calculations for accuracy
- Observe ability to create compelling financial arguments
- Verify understanding of factors affecting payback period
- Review completed financial analysis worksheets

- Update financial spreadsheet with current prices
- Prepare simple demonstration system

**Step-by-Step Procedure:**
1. **Digital Tools Overview (15 minutes)**
   - Explain the role of software in design process:
     - Validation of manual calculations
     - Creating professional reports
     - Exploring different scenarios quickly
   - Emphasize importance of understanding manual calculations first
   - Introduce tools to be demonstrated:
     - PVWatts for production estimation
     - IRR spreadsheet for financial analysis
     - (Optional) PVsyst if advanced users are present

2. **PVWatts Demonstration (30 minutes)**
   - Access PVWatts website or offline version
   - Enter Mosul location data (34.3°N, 43.1°E)
   - Input system parameters:
     - DC System Size (from sizing exercise)
     - Module type (Standard)
     - Array type (Fixed roof mount)
     - System losses (default 14%)
     - Tilt angle (match roof or 30° optimal)
     - Azimuth (180° south)
   - Run calculation and interpret results:
     - Monthly production estimates
     - Annual total
     - Compare to manual calculations

3. **Financial Spreadsheet Tool (30 minutes)**
   - Open IRR_Slider spreadsheet
   - Enter system parameters from sizing exercise
   - Input current market prices
   - Show how changing parameters affects results:
     - Varying panel quantities
     - Different battery capacities
     - Alternative component selections
   - Demonstrate customer proposal generation
   - Share digital copy with trainees

**What to Say:**
"These digital tools help us work more efficiently, but you must understand the manual calculations first. In Mosul, internet access can be unreliable, so we need both approaches. PVWatts gives us production estimates based on historical weather data, while our financial spreadsheet helps calculate long-term returns. These tools create professional reports that build customer confidence."

**Common Questions & Answers:**
Q: "Are these tools accurate for Mosul conditions?"
A: "PVWatts uses global solar data that is fairly accurate for Mosul. However, it doesn't account for dust, which is why we add additional loss factors (5-10%) for our location."

Q: "What if we don't have reliable internet access?"
A: "All these tools have offline versions you can run locally. I'll provide them on USB drives, and we'll practice using both online and offline options."

**Troubleshooting & Adaptations:**
If internet access is unavailable:
- Use offline Excel versions of calculators
- Work with downloaded screenshots of PVWatts
- Focus on interpreting results rather than data entry

If computer access is limited:
- Conduct as demonstration only
- Provide printed examples of tool outputs
- Share digital tools via WhatsApp for later practice

**Assessment Method:**
- Observe ability to navigate software tools
- Check understanding of output interpretation
- Compare digital results with manual calculations
- Ask questions about when to use digital vs. manual methods

---

# DAY 3: COMPONENT SELECTION & SAFETY

## Overview
Day 3 focuses on selecting appropriate components, understanding specification sheets, and addressing critical safety considerations. Trainees will learn to create complete bills of materials, compare different products based on quality and price, and understand the special safety requirements of DC solar circuits.

## Preparation Checklist
□ Slide deck (slides 18-22) loaded on computer
□ 25 printed specification sheet comparison matrices
□ 25 Bill of Materials templates
□ 25 LCOE calculation worksheets
□ Specification sheets for different brands/models:
  □ Solar panels (mono, poly, bifacial)
  □ Inverters (string, hybrid)
  □ Batteries (lithium, lead-acid)
  □ Mounting systems
□ Current Mosul market price list
□ Sample components (if available):
  □ Solar panel
  □ Battery
  □ Inverter
  □ DC cables and connectors
  □ Protection devices
□ Wire samples (proper DC wire vs. AC wire)
□ MC4 connectors and crimping tool
□ Fuses and breakers (DC-rated)
□ Photos of counterfeit components vs. genuine
□ Photos of installation failures due to improper components

## Hour-by-Hour Schedule
| Time | Activity | Materials | Setup Notes |
|------|----------|-----------|------------|
| 08:30-09:00 | Prepare room, arrange displays | All components | Create component stations |
| 09:00-09:30 | Day 2 Recap & Introduction | Whiteboard, Day 2 worksheets | Highlight connection to sizing |
| 09:30-11:00 | Specification Sheet Reading | Component specs, comparison matrix | Sort spec sheets by type |
| 11:00-11:15 | Break | Tea/water | - |
| 11:15-12:45 | Bill of Materials Workshop | BoM templates, price lists | Write LCOE formula on board |
| 12:45-13:45 | Lunch | - | - |
| 13:45-15:00 | DC vs. AC Safety | Wire samples, protection devices | Test demonstration components |
| 15:00-16:30 | Quality vs. Counterfeit | Component samples, photos | Create comparison displays |

## Detailed Activity Guide: Day 2 Recap & Introduction
**Purpose:** Review key calculations from Day 2 and connect them to today's focus on component selection.

**Materials:**
- Whiteboard and markers
- Completed worksheets from Day 2
- Example system design from Day 2

**Preparation:**
- Select good examples of sizing calculations from Day 2
- Write Day 3 agenda on board
- Prepare key review questions

**Step-by-Step Procedure:**
1. **Welcome and Agenda (5 minutes)**
   - Welcome trainees back
   - Review agenda for Day 3
   - Explain connection between sizing and component selection

2. **Sizing Review (15 minutes)**
   - Ask key questions about Day 2 content:
     - "Who remembers how to calculate array size?"
     - "How do we determine battery capacity?"
     - "What factors affect inverter sizing?"
   - Have different trainees answer each question
   - Clarify any misconceptions

3. **Today's Focus Introduction (10 minutes)**
   - Explain importance of component selection:
     - Quality determines system reliability
     - Specifications must match system requirements
     - Proper components ensure safety
   - Preview the day's activities
   - Connect to real-world installation success

**What to Say:**
"Yesterday we calculated the size of our system components. Today we'll select the specific brands and models that will meet these requirements. This is where many installers make costly mistakes - choosing components that are incompatible, unsafe, or counterfeit. By the end of today, you'll know how to select quality components and create accurate, complete bills of materials."

**Common Questions & Answers:**
Q: "Can we just use the cheapest components that meet our size requirements?"
A: "Initial cost is only one factor. Quality components last longer, perform better, and have fewer problems. We'll learn how to balance cost and quality for different customer budgets."

Q: "How do we know which brands are reliable in Iraq?"
A: "We'll discuss specific brands available in the Mosul market and show you how to assess quality even for unfamiliar brands."

## Detailed Activity Guide: Specification Sheet Reading
**Purpose:** Develop the ability to read and interpret technical specifications for solar components and make informed selection decisions.

**Materials:**
- Specification sheets for multiple brands/models:
  - Solar panels (4-5 different types)
  - Inverters (3-4 different models)
  - Batteries (lithium and lead-acid options)
- Specification comparison matrix templates
- Highlighters or colored pens
- Physical components if available

**Preparation:**
- Organize specification sheets by component type
- Create component stations around the room
- Prepare comparison example to demonstrate
- Highlight key specifications on sample sheets

**Step-by-Step Procedure:**
1. **Panel Specifications (30 minutes)**
   - Show actual solar panel specification sheet
   - Identify critical parameters:
     - Wattage (power output)
     - Voltage (Voc and Vmp)
     - Current (Isc and Imp)
     - Temperature coefficient (critical in Mosul heat)
     - Physical dimensions and weight
     - Warranty terms and conditions
   - Demonstrate how to compare different models:
     - Price per watt
     - Efficiency percentage
     - Temperature performance
     - Warranty period
   - Explain which specifications matter most for Mosul climate

2. **Battery Specifications (30 minutes)**
   - Show lithium and lead-acid specifications side by side
   - Highlight key differences:
     - Capacity (kWh or Ah)
     - Voltage (12V, 24V, 48V)
     - Depth of Discharge (DoD)
     - Cycle life
     - Temperature limitations
     - Weight and size
   - Explain battery selection factors:
     - Lithium advantages: higher DoD, longer life, less maintenance
     - Lead-acid advantages: lower initial cost, locally available
     - Temperature considerations for Mosul
   - Discuss how to verify capacity claims (common fraud area)

3. **Inverter Specifications (30 minutes)**
   - Show specifications for different inverter types
   - Identify key parameters:
     - Power rating (kW)
     - Input voltage range
     - Battery compatibility
     - Efficiency
     - Features (monitoring, etc.)
     - Protection capabilities
   - Discuss inverter selection factors:
     - Pure sine wave vs. modified sine wave
     - Grid-tie capability
     - Surge capacity
     - Communication features
   - Explain compatibility requirements with other components

**What to Say:**
"In Mosul's extreme climate, temperature coefficients are critical when selecting panels. A typical panel loses 0.4-0.5% efficiency for each degree above 25°C. When panels can reach 65-70°C in summer, this means a potential 16-20% reduction in output. Look for panels with lower temperature coefficients (-0.35% or better) to maximize production in our hot climate."

**Common Questions & Answers:**
Q: "How do we know if components are compatible with each other?"
A: "Check voltage and current ratings. Inverter input must match panel output voltage range, battery voltage must match inverter battery input, etc. We'll create compatibility charts for common components."

Q: "Is it better to choose components from the same manufacturer?"
A: "Not necessarily, but it can simplify warranty claims. Focus on compatibility and quality rather than brand matching."

**Troubleshooting & Adaptations:**
If specification sheets are limited:
- Create simplified spec sheets with key parameters
- Share digital copies via WhatsApp or email
- Use projected images for group discussion

If trainees struggle with technical parameters:
- Focus on the 3-4 most critical specifications
- Create a decision flowchart for selection
- Use color coding for important specifications

**Assessment Method:**
- Check completed comparison matrices for accuracy
- Observe ability to identify critical specifications
- Ask questions about selection rationale
- Verify understanding of compatibility requirements

## Detailed Activity Guide: Bill of Materials Workshop
**Purpose:** Learn to create comprehensive, accurate bills of materials with all system components and calculate total system costs and LCOE.

**Materials:**
- Bill of Materials templates
- Price lists for components in Mosul market
- LCOE calculation worksheets
- Calculators
- Whiteboard for demonstrations
- System designs from previous day

**Preparation:**
- Create a comprehensive price list for all components and accessories
- Prepare a sample BoM with all required categories
- Write the LCOE formula on the board:
  - LCOE = Total Lifetime Cost ÷ Total Lifetime Energy Production
- Create sample system for demonstration

**Step-by-Step Procedure:**
1. **Complete BoM Introduction (15 minutes)**
   - Explain the importance of comprehensive BoMs:
     - Ensures accurate quoting
     - Prevents missing components
     - Facilitates procurement
     - Provides professional documentation
   - Show example of complete BoM
   - Discuss consequences of incomplete BoMs

2. **Component Categories (20 minutes)**
   - Review all component categories needed:
     - Major components (panels, inverters, batteries)
     - Mounting structure and hardware
     - Cables, connectors, and junction boxes
     - Protection devices (fuses, breakers, SPDs)
     - Grounding equipment
     - Monitoring systems
     - Labels and documentation
     - Installation materials and consumables
   - Show examples of often-forgotten items:
     - Cable ties, labels, conduit
     - Grounding equipment
     - Signs and safety documentation

3. **Cost Calculation Practice (40 minutes)**
   - Use the system designed on Day 2
   - Guide trainees through creating complete BoM
   - Use current Mosul market prices
   - Calculate total system cost
   - Include contingency factor (typically 5-10%)
   - Discuss potential cost optimizations
   - Compare different component options

4. **LCOE Calculation (30 minutes)**
   - Explain LCOE concept:
     - Total lifetime cost ÷ Total lifetime energy
     - Includes initial cost + replacements + maintenance
     - Allows comparison between energy sources
   - Demonstrate calculation:
     - 25-year system life
     - Battery replacement (year 7-10)
     - Annual maintenance
     - Total energy production (daily kWh × 365 × 25)
   - Calculate LCOE in IQD/kWh
   - Compare to generator cost (~250-300 IQD/kWh)
   - Compare to grid cost (~50-70 IQD/kWh when available)

**What to Say:**
"A professional solar installer always creates a complete Bill of Materials. Many installers in Mosul fail because they forget critical small components or underestimate quantities. When you're on a rooftop and missing a connector or cable gland, the whole project stops. This careful planning separates professionals from amateurs and directly affects your profit margin."

**Common Questions & Answers:**
Q: "How much contingency should we include?"
A: "For standard residential systems in Mosul, 5-10% is typical. For difficult installations or remote locations, consider 10-15%. This covers unexpected needs and small variations."

Q: "How do we handle price fluctuations in our quotes?"
A: "Specify quote validity period (typically 7-14 days) and include clauses for significant price changes. Build relationships with suppliers to get advance notice of price changes."

**Troubleshooting & Adaptations:**
If current market prices aren't available:
- Use relative pricing (low, medium, high)
- Focus on proportional costs rather than exact figures
- Create price ranges for different quality levels

If calculation proves difficult:
- Provide a simplified LCOE calculator
- Focus on key components rather than exhaustive lists
- Use pre-calculated examples as references

**Assessment Method:**
- Check BoM completeness (should include all component categories)
- Verify accurate quantity calculations
- Review price research and reasonableness
- Assess LCOE calculation accuracy

## Detailed Activity Guide: DC vs. AC Safety
**Purpose:** Understand the critical safety differences between DC and AC systems and learn proper component selection for solar installations.

**Materials:**
- DC-rated cables (solar-specific)
- Standard AC cables
- DC circuit breakers and fuses
- AC circuit breakers
- MC4 connectors and crimping tools
- Disconnects and isolation switches
- Photos of safety failures and fires
- Safety equipment (gloves, etc.)

**Preparation:**
- Set up display of proper vs. improper components
- Prepare safety demonstration area
- Create safety comparison chart
- Test all demonstration equipment

**Step-by-Step Procedure:**
1. **DC vs. AC Fundamentals (15 minutes)**
   - Explain critical differences:
     - DC doesn't cross zero (arcs don't self-extinguish)
     - DC requires special breakers and disconnects
     - DC voltage remains constant (higher continuous stress)
     - Solar DC voltages can be much higher than household AC
   - Show photos of failures caused by improper components
   - Explain NEC/IEC requirements for solar DC circuits

2. **Cable Selection (20 minutes)**
   - Show proper DC solar cable:
     - Double-insulated
     - UV-resistant
     - Temperature rated (90°C+)
     - Proper gauge for current
   - Compare with standard household cable
   - Demonstrate proper sizing calculation:
     - Based on current (Isc × 1.25)
     - Adjusted for temperature
     - Accounting for voltage drop (3% max)
   - Explain consequences of undersized cables:
     - Energy loss
     - Overheating
     - Fire risk

3. **Protection Devices (20 minutes)**
   - Demonstrate proper DC-rated devices:
     - Circuit breakers
     - Fuses
     - Disconnects
     - Surge protection devices
   - Explain why AC breakers cannot be used for DC
   - Show proper device ratings:
     - Voltage rating (must exceed maximum system voltage)
     - Current rating (125% of maximum current)
     - Interrupt rating (must handle DC fault current)

4. **Proper Connections (20 minutes)**
   - Demonstrate MC4 connector assembly:
     - Proper wire stripping
     - Correct crimping technique
     - Weather sealing
     - Testing for secure connection
   - Show common connection failures
   - Explain importance of proper torque on electrical connections

**What to Say:**
"Many solar fires in Iraq are caused by using the wrong components. AC circuit breakers cannot safely interrupt DC current from solar panels. When an arc forms, it doesn't self-extinguish and can reach temperatures over 3,000°C - hot enough to melt metal and start fires. This is why we must use proper DC-rated components, even though they cost more. Your reputation and your customers' safety depend on it."

**Common Questions & Answers:**
Q: "Can't we just use heavy-duty AC components to save money?"
A: "No. Even heavy-duty AC breakers lack the arc suppression needed for DC. They may work temporarily but will eventually fail catastrophically - often causing fires."

Q: "How do we know if a component is properly DC-rated?"
A: "Look for specific DC ratings (voltage and current) marked with straight lines or the DC symbol. AC ratings use the ~ symbol. Always check datasheets or packaging to confirm DC rating."

**Troubleshooting & Adaptations:**
If demonstration components aren't available:
- Use detailed photos and diagrams
- Show videos of proper vs. improper components
- Create clear visual comparison charts

If technical level varies widely:
- Focus on practical identification rather than electrical theory
- Use simple "use this, not that" examples
- Create visual selection guides for common components

**Assessment Method:**
- Quiz on identifying proper DC components
- Observe connector assembly technique (if demonstration is possible)
- Verify understanding of safety risks
- Check ability to calculate proper cable sizes

## Detailed Activity Guide: Quality vs. Counterfeit
**Purpose:** Learn to identify genuine quality components and avoid counterfeit products common in the Iraqi market.

**Materials:**
- Examples of genuine components (or detailed photos)
- Examples of counterfeit components (or detailed photos)
- Checklists for identifying genuine products
- Magnifying glasses for close inspection
- Contact information for reliable suppliers in Mosul

**Preparation:**
- Create side-by-side displays of genuine vs. counterfeit
- Prepare detailed photos showing key differences
- Create checklists for each component type
- List of common counterfeiting methods

**Step-by-Step Procedure:**
1. **Counterfeit Overview (15 minutes)**
   - Explain the counterfeit problem in Iraqi market
   - Discuss common counterfeit components:
     - Batteries (especially lithium)
     - Solar panels
     - Name-brand inverters
   - Explain consequences:
     - Poor performance
     - Short lifespan
     - Safety hazards
     - Warranty issues
     - Reputation damage

2. **Panel Authentication (20 minutes)**
   - Show identification features of genuine panels:
     - Serial number format and location
     - Proper certification markings
     - Junction box quality
     - Frame construction
     - Cell appearance and consistency
   - Demonstrate inspection techniques:
     - Check serial number with manufacturer
     - Inspect label quality and information
     - Examine physical construction

3. **Battery Authentication (20 minutes)**
   - Show identification features of genuine batteries:
     - Weight (counterfeit often lighter)
     - Manufacturing codes
     - Terminal construction
     - Label quality
     - Packaging
   - Discuss common frauds:
     - Lead weights in lithium batteries
     - Capacity misrepresentation
     - Recycled cells presented as new
   - Demonstrate basic testing methods

4. **Inverter Authentication (20 minutes)**
   - Show identification features of genuine inverters:
     - Serial number verification
     - Internal construction (if visible)
     - Weight and build quality
     - Software interface
     - Packaging and documentation
   - Discuss reputable brands available in Mosul
   - Explain how to verify with manufacturers

5. **Reliable Sourcing (15 minutes)**
   - Discuss strategies for avoiding counterfeits:
     - Buy from authorized dealers
     - Check online verification tools
     - Verify warranties
     - Be suspicious of unusually low prices
   - Share contacts for reliable suppliers in Mosul
   - Discuss importance of building supplier relationships

**What to Say:**
"Counterfeit products are a serious problem in our market. A fake battery that claims 200Ah might actually be 100Ah with weights added inside. Counterfeit panels may have fake certification labels. These products not only cheat your customer but damage your reputation when they fail early. Learning to identify genuine products is essential for long-term business success."

**Common Questions & Answers:**
Q: "How can we compete when others use cheaper counterfeit products?"
A: "Educate your customers about the risks. Show them comparison photos and performance data. Build your reputation on quality and reliability. In the long run, happy customers bring more business through referrals."

Q: "What if we can't afford original brand-name products?"
A: "There are legitimate economy brands that offer reasonable quality without being counterfeit. It's better to use an honest economy brand than a fake premium brand."

**Troubleshooting & Adaptations:**
If counterfeit examples aren't available:
- Use detailed photographs
- Create comparison charts
- Share stories of counterfeit failures

If trainees are familiar with local suppliers:
- Have open discussion about local market conditions
- Create a group-sourced list of trusted suppliers
- Discuss pricing strategies when competing with counterfeit products

**Assessment Method:**
- Conduct identification exercise with mixed genuine/counterfeit examples
- Check understanding of authentication methods
- Review knowledge of reliable sourcing strategies
- Observe ability to identify warning signs

---

These improved facilitator guides for Days 1-3 now include:
- Detailed hour-by-hour schedules
- Comprehensive materials lists with quantities
- Step-by-step procedures with timing
- "What to Say" examples with local Mosul context
- Common Questions & Answers sections
- Specific troubleshooting adaptations
- Clear assessment methods
- Cultural notes specific to Mosul

The guides are designed to be practical and usable by first-time technical trainers while maintaining professional pedagogical structure.

# IMPROVED FACILITATOR GUIDES

# DAY 1: SITE ASSESSMENT & LOAD ANALYSIS

## Overview
This first day establishes the foundation of solar design by teaching trainees how to properly assess a site and calculate energy needs. These critical skills determine if a site is suitable for solar and what system size will be required.

## Preparation Checklist
□ Slide deck (slides 1-11) loaded on computer
□ 25 printed site survey worksheets
□ 25 load calculation templates
□ 25 sun-path charts for Mosul's latitude (34°N)
□ Clinometer apps installed on at least 5 phones (test before class)
□ Compass apps or physical compasses (at least 5)
□ Calculators or calculator apps
□ Solar vocabulary cards in Arabic/English (25 sets)
□ Appliance power rating reference sheet (25 copies)
□ 5 clipboards for outdoor activities
□ Building layout map of training location
□ Sample completed site survey form for demonstration
□ Whiteboard and markers

## Hour-by-Hour Schedule
| Time | Activity | Materials | Setup Notes |
|------|----------|-----------|------------|
| 08:30-09:00 | Prepare room, test equipment | All materials | Check phones have clinometer apps |
| 09:00-09:30 | Welcome & Energy Context | Slide 1-3 | Arrange seating in groups |
| 09:30-11:00 | Solar Fundamentals & Types | Slides 4-7, vocabulary cards | Post vocabulary on walls |
| 11:00-11:15 | Break | Tea/water | - |
| 11:15-12:45 | Site Survey Practice | Survey forms, clinometers, compasses | Identify outdoor practice areas |
| 12:45-13:45 | Lunch | - | - |
| 13:45-15:00 | Load Calculation Workshop | Calculation sheets, appliance chart | Example calculation on board |
| 15:00-16:30 | Sun-Path Analysis | Sun-path charts, clipboards | Prepare outdoor viewing area |

## Detailed Activity Guide: Welcome & Energy Context
**Purpose:** Establish the solar opportunity in Iraq and set expectations for the training program.

**Materials:**
- Slides 1-3
- Whiteboard and markers
- Name tags or cards

**Preparation:**
- Write welcome message in Arabic and English
- Prepare a simple chart showing Iraq's energy gap
- Have statistics on diesel generator costs in Mosul

**Step-by-Step Procedure:**
1. **Welcome and Introductions (15 minutes)**
   - Welcome trainees in Arabic and English
   - Introduce yourself and your background
   - Have trainees briefly introduce themselves:
     - Name
     - Background
     - Experience with electricity/solar
     - What they hope to learn

2. **Training Program Overview (5 minutes)**
   - Explain the 6-day program structure
   - Mention certification and follow-up opportunities
   - Set expectations for hands-on, practical learning
   - Explain daily schedule (start time, breaks, end time)

3. **Iraq's Energy Context (10 minutes)**
   - Present Iraq's energy reality:
     - Current electricity supply (average 15-18 hours/day in Mosul)
     - Reliance on diesel generators (costs, pollution)
     - Solar potential (2,800+ sun hours annually)
   - Show photos of successful solar installations in Mosul

**What to Say:**
"Welcome to this solar training program. Iraq faces significant energy challenges with power outages and expensive generators. But we also have abundant sunshine - over 2,800 hours per year. Solar can provide reliable electricity while creating good jobs. By the end of this week, you'll have the skills to design and install professional solar systems."

**Common Questions & Answers:**
Q: "Is solar really cheaper than generators in the long run?"
A: "Yes. While the upfront cost is higher, a typical home solar system in Mosul pays for itself in 3-5 years through generator fuel savings. Generators also need regular maintenance and eventual replacement."

Q: "What about government policies for solar in Iraq?"
A: "The Iraqi government is increasingly supporting renewable energy. The Central Bank has green loan initiatives, and some import taxes have been reduced for solar equipment."

## Detailed Activity Guide: Solar Fundamentals & System Types
**Purpose:** Establish core solar concepts and vocabulary while explaining different system architectures.

**Materials:**
- Slides 4-7
- Solar vocabulary cards (Arabic/English)
- System architecture diagrams
- Photos of real Iraqi installations

**Preparation:**
- Test all slide animations
- Display vocabulary cards around room
- Prepare physical props if available (small solar cell, inverter, etc.)

**Step-by-Step Procedure:**
1. **Basic Solar Principles (30 minutes)**
   - Explain how solar panels work (photovoltaic effect)
   - Define key components:
     - Solar panels (األلواح الشمسية)
     - Inverter (العاكس)
     - Charge controller (منظم الشحن)
     - Batteries (البطاريات)
   - Explain DC vs. AC electricity
   - Show physical examples if available

2. **System Types (30 minutes)**
   - Explain three main architectures with diagrams:
     - Off-grid (غير متصل بالشبكة): No connection to national grid
     - Grid-tied (متصل بالشبكة): Connects to grid, no batteries
     - Hybrid (هجين): Connects to grid with battery backup
   - Discuss which is most common in Mosul and why
   - Show photos of each type installed in Iraq

3. **Benefits Discussion (30 minutes)**
   - Divide into small groups
   - Have groups list benefits of solar for:
     - Homeowners
     - Businesses
     - Communities
   - Share and discuss findings
   - Add any missed points:
     - Economic: compare to diesel costs
     - Environmental: reduced emissions, noise
     - Practical: reliable power during outages
     - Business opportunity: growing market

**What to Say:**
"In Mosul, we typically see hybrid systems most often because they provide backup power during frequent grid outages. The national grid is unreliable, providing only about 15-18 hours of electricity per day, and diesel is expensive at approximately 1,000-1,200 IQD per liter. A hybrid solar system with batteries allows customers to have 24-hour power without the noise, maintenance, and fuel costs of generators."

**Common Questions & Answers:**
Q: "How long do solar systems last?"
A: "Quality solar panels typically last 25+ years, with performance guarantees of 80% output after 25 years. Batteries last 7-10 years for lithium and 3-5 years for lead-acid if properly maintained. Inverters typically need replacement after 10-15 years."

Q: "What happens during dusty or cloudy days?"
A: "System sizing accounts for this variability. Batteries store excess energy from sunny days for use during less productive periods. In Mosul, we typically design for 1-2 days of autonomy."

**Troubleshooting & Adaptations:**
If electricity is unavailable for projector:
- Use printed handouts of key slides
- Draw system diagrams on whiteboard
- Use physical components for demonstration

If trainees have varying technical backgrounds:
- Pair technically stronger trainees with those needing support
- Provide additional visual aids for complex concepts

## Detailed Activity Guide: Load Calculation Workshop
**Purpose:** Learn to accurately calculate a customer's energy needs, which is fundamental to proper system sizing.

**Materials:**
- Load calculation worksheets
- Calculators
- Appliance power reference charts
- Whiteboard and markers
- Sample home scenario descriptions

**Preparation:**
- Write calculation formula on board: Power (W) × Hours = Energy (Wh)
- Prepare typical Mosul home example with common appliances
- Create table on board for demonstration calculation
- Prepare list of common Iraqi appliance power ratings

**Step-by-Step Procedure:**
1. **Explain Load Assessment (15 minutes)**
   - Define electrical load: appliances using electricity
   - Show the calculation formula: Power (W) × Hours = Energy (Wh)
   - Explain converting to kWh (÷1000)
   - Differentiate between:
     - Continuous loads (refrigerator)
     - Intermittent loads (TV, lights)
     - High-surge loads (water pump, AC)

2. **Demonstrate Calculation (20 minutes)**
   - Use a typical Mosul home example:
     - 8 LED lights (10W each) × 5 hours = 400 Wh
     - 1 Refrigerator (150W) × 24 hours × 0.4 (duty cycle) = 1,440 Wh
     - 2 Ceiling fans (70W each) × 8 hours = 1,120 Wh
     - 1 TV (120W) × 6 hours = 720 Wh
     - Total = 3,680 Wh = 3.68 kWh daily
   - Apply safety margin (multiply by 1.2) = 4.42 kWh
   - Explain importance of accuracy in estimations

3. **Practice Calculations (30 minutes)**
   - Provide worksheet with blank load table
   - Have trainees work in pairs to calculate:
     - Their own home loads
     - OR provided case study scenario
   - Circulate to check calculations and assist
   - Address common errors and questions

4. **Critical vs. Non-critical Loads (20 minutes)**
   - Explain concept of load prioritization
   - Have trainees mark which loads are critical
   - Discuss how this affects system design
   - Calculate sub-total for critical loads only
   - Explain backup circuit design concept

**What to Say:**
"Accurate load calculation is the foundation of good system design. If you underestimate, the customer won't have enough power. If you overestimate, the system becomes unnecessarily expensive. In Mosul, load patterns change seasonally - air conditioners in summer, heaters in winter. Always discuss these seasonal variations with customers."

**Common Questions & Answers:**
Q: "How do we handle appliances that don't run continuously, like refrigerators?"
A: "Use a duty cycle factor. Refrigerators typically run 30-40% of the time, so multiply the hours by 0.3-0.4."

Q: "What about air conditioners? They use a lot of power."
A: "Air conditioners are challenging because they have high surge currents and variable consumption. For a 1.5 ton AC (common in Mosul), calculate about 1,500W × hours used × 0.7 (typical duty cycle)."

**Troubleshooting & Adaptations:**
If trainees struggle with calculations:
- Work through examples step by step on the board
- Provide pre-calculated examples to compare
- Use simple rounded numbers

If load patterns are very different from examples:
- Ask trainees to share typical household usage from their experience
- Adjust examples to match local conditions
- Discuss how different economic levels affect energy usage

**Assessment Method:**
- Check load calculation accuracy (within 10%)
- Verify understanding of duty cycles
- Observe ability to identify critical loads
- Review completed worksheets for thoroughness
